description:
Invented by 9 year old Lindsay Berstein, winner of the National Young Game inventors Contest.

The object of the game is to be the first to fill your Rapunzel braid up with color form braid pieces.

For ages 4 and up.

name: Monopoly: Southampton Edition
description:
A monopoly (from Greek monos μόνος (alone or single) + polein πωλεῖν (to sell)) exists when a specific person or enterprise is the only supplier of a particular commodity.

Monopoly is a roll-and-move game where players move around the game board buying or trading properties, developing their properties with houses and hotels. When opponents land on players owned property, the owning player collects rent from the landing player. Owning sets of properties increases the rent paid to the player who owns them, by the player who lands on the square. The ultimate goal is to have the most money and drive opponents into bankruptcy.

The classic Monopoly with constructions and other elements from Southampton, in the United Kingdom.
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Player Elimination, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Trading
publishers: Hasbro, Parker Brothers, Winning Moves UK Ltd.

name: Don't Blow Your Top
description:
From the box:

"Careful! Careful! You never know,
The one you add may make it blow!"

A spinner is used to determine how many marbles each player in turn must drop in a hat that sits on top of a balloon-man's head. Small strips with a texture resembling extremely rough sandpaper are attached under the hat; these sit gently on the surface of the balloon-head. At some point, the weight of the marbles becomes too much and the hat-strips pop the balloon. The winner is the person with the fewest marbles in their posession when the balloon bursts.

The game was designed by the well-known Marvin Glass & Associates design studio.

name: Napoleonic Quick March
description:
Napoleonic Quick March is an army level command game with corps and divisions as the major maneuver elements. Players dice for initiative order, draw command cards that act as division and corps commander interpretations of battle orders. Each player moves divisions in an attempt to affect a combined arms attack.

Novelty is the grid movement system where the board is divided into a point grid system. It allows complex maneuver similar to standard "measure and move" miniature games, but needs no rulers. Allows for more dynamic play than hexagonal grids with eight possible positions rather than six.

Major battles of the era can be played rather quickly, and a small number of troops are needed. It is an excellent game for beginners to get into the era, and it has enough complexity to keep veteran gamers interested.

The rules are full color, brief, well written, and easy to follow. Rule book includes a sample scenario in the back along with scenario building guide and open gaming army development matrix. Rules include basic and advanced rules, command cards, and quirky illustrations that bring a smile.

Bottom line is game is fast and entertaining.
mechanics: Campaign / Battle Card Driven, Dice Rolling, Simultaneous Action Selection, Variable Phase Order, Variable Player Powers

name: Yotta Know Birds
description:
Part of a series of "Yotta Know..." games on different topics, Yotta Know Birds is a game played on a six-by-six grid board on which players place cards depicting birds to be identified. The first player to identify seven birds wins the round. Rolling dice adds a randomizing element to gameplay, while a handicap system allows players of varying knowledge levels to play against each other.
The game uses a deck of 60 birds, all of which are found in North America.
Expanded by:

Yotta Know Mammals
Yotta Know Waterfowl

name: Operation Husky (1943)
description:
“OPERATION HUSKY” (10 July – 17 August 1943)

American, British and Canadian troops land in the South of the Island. Their aim is to reach Messina, as the final plan is to liberate Italy from the German occupation. It is likely that the Axis would begin to evacuate forces from the island in the very near future, and it is vitally important that they are destroyed or captured before they can leave Sicily. This ensures that any subsequent invasion of the Italian mainland would be faced by far fewer Axis troops.
The most immediate objectives are airfields and ports in the advance towards Messina.
Depending on his reinforcement schedule, the Axis player may attempt to delay Allies conquest of the island, or decisively defeat the Allies by a strong counterattack.

Game Components:
- Map Board
- Sheet of Counters
- Rules Handout
- One 6 sided die
categories: Print & Play, Wargame, World War II

name: Quick & Dirty
description:
This game comes in 3 versions: "Für Frauen" (for women), "Für Männer" (For men)"Für Manager" (For Manager).

It is a mixture between "Bulls**t-Bingo" and "Once upon a time". One Player draws random cards with words on it, usually words coming from management areas ("Shareholder-value") and he has to put them into a speech.
Every time he says one keyword the other players can mark them on a "Bingo"-Board and they get points for - well for Bingo basically.

name: OPORD
description:
The game is on the market. Anyone attenting RECON in Orlando is welcome to stop by the Flaming Monkey Games booth for a quick demo. :)

OPORD is a game designed specifically to allow players to experience the sensation of launching a coordinated combined arms attack. The game challenges a player with modern land warfare based upon existing tactical doctrine at the battalion level, but condensed in such a way as to make the make exiting and playable. Players develop and execute operations to affect a coordinated tactical victory over their opponent. To win, a player will have to successfully execute the instructions on his Mission Card while keeping the opponent from doing likewise.

In modern warfare, there is no shoot, maneuver sequence, as all shooting and maneuvering is simultaneous. This is a key difference between modern warfare and that of WWII, and thus a main component of OPORD. Movement is continuous, and shooting is sustained. This is a key concept built into the OPORD game engine. The variable turn sequence forces tactical forethought beyond the old “my turn, your turn” design mentality, and as a result players get a sense of fluidity of motion throughout the game.

Another key aspect of OPORD is the mission card driven objectives. Players are not playing to slay each other’s armies, since this is akin to senseless banzai charges with no real aim other than to roll dice. Rather, the game is set around typical “real world” sorts of missions that soldiers are given to accomplish. Seize this hill, secure this route, recon in force here, set up a defense there—all of these are typical missions you’ll see in your mission cards. And like the real world, you job is to use your troops and support elements to accomplish the mission.

In short, OPORD is a game that very closely relates the gaming experience to that of a real life Battalion Commander but in a fun way. Receive your orders, allocate your troops and resources, design your plan, execute your plan, and complete the mission.

A typical turn. Both players dice for initiative and turn sequence. Initiative is obvious, winner goes first. Sequencing dice determines the player's turn sequence. Sequencing can be shoot/move/fight or move/shoot/fight. the initiative winner goes first in the first two phases, while in the third phase "fight" all combat is simultaneous. Movement variables are factored into the terrain boards, so there is no worry about modifiers for moving. In combat, units shoot/fight collectively if in the same sector, or individually if in separate sectors. Essentially both players dice (attack dice for phasing player, defend dice for non-phasing). The interactive nature of every phase of every turn means no players are passive, which gives both a sense of fluidity. Results are based upon combat dicing. Units can be depleted, eliminated, or forced to withdraw. The object of the game is to accomplish your mission and deny the enemy his. While there are some mission cards that are all out attacks, most of the missions require you to combat in support of your own mission or to deny the other's.

Terrain boards are modular, so there is no limit to the size map one can create. But a game comes with six maps.
mechanics: Area Movement, Campaign / Battle Card Driven, Modular Board, Secret Unit Deployment, Simultaneous Action Selection, Variable Phase Order

name: Ready Fence
description:
This is a cardgame for 2 players.
Players are fencing athletes fighting each other.
Players share a common deck and use cards to Move, Attack and to Defend.
Available for free download (http://www.webalice.it/alecrespi/html/warpspawn.html) or in the files section.
The winner is the one who reaches 5 (or 15) points.
mechanics: Campaign / Battle Card Driven, Open Drafting

name: Warriors of the Dark Star: The Age of the Neutron Wars
description:
This was the first in a series of tactical space combat games linked to Galaxy-Foundation Games' strategic Battle for Andromeda: Conflict for a Trillion Suns! series. Further games using the same rules were Duel of the Sun Slayers, Vengeance Crusaders vs. The Monads, and the probably never published Plunderers of the Planets.

Galaxy-Foundation Games licensed Taurus Games to produce the initial print run of the game (6,000 copies, according to a later GFG catalog). Whether GFG produced any further copies is unknown; at least one later game in the series included a completely rewritten Warriors of the Dark Star rulebook, but no copy of the original game with that rulebook has been seen.

From the GFG catalog (reproduced verbatim):


The Warriors of the Dark Star - in the Age of the Neutron Wars covers the Tactical aspects of the same subjects above, except that the player is concerned with the piloting of ONE ship, its intricate operations, the application of SPECIFIC SECRET WEAPONS, individually applied, ship-to-ship single combat, Tactically oriented Battles, similar to a duel between Battleships, etc.




Often "WD" games are issued immediately with a companion "BFA" game; while the BFA game has all the ships in quantity as well as specialized weapons systems, the "WD" series takes in a particular FEATURE emphasized STRATEGICALLY in RFA, and allows a "Close-Up" in-depth treatment of particular ships. Thus, a war involving 20 or 30 ships of which 12 of these units are representative of a Special Dreadnaught with unique capabilities, fighting an ENEMY with ships of unusual properties, is concentrated on. "WD" would concern itself with the broad exposition of these forces in the form of a single ship which would be cast in a series of Scenarios that would reflect the small battles occurring in ONE HEX of "BFA" to give the emotional and personal "FEEL" not of an Admiral of the Fleet, but of a Captain of one vessel, where his piloting skills and crew efficiency is most vital! This does not cover a single bizarre ship in BFA that might be of special use, but of the Main Line items that won or lost the war; the ones that carried the major burden of the battle, whose over-all effect was sufficient to provide subject matter on what ONE ship would teach players that would help them understand the LARGE view of BFA. It is also a TRAINING AID in teaching Captains in individual combat in WD to become Commanders after the TEST OF BATTLE of fleets in BFA. Of course, if popular demand requires special, and/or additional types exposed in BFA, not covered in WD to be produced, an extension kit to HD for a minor cost of $2 to $4 is printed allowing the ND kit an unlimited number of "Expansion modules"

name: Know Islam: Know Peace
description:
This game is easy to learn and simple to play. Each player or team selects one of the yellow game boards. One player identified as the "caller" selects a blue information card and reads the Islamic term or name at the top. Players that have the word on their boards are asked to define or describe the importance of the Islamic practice, person or event. If they do so correctly, they receive a chip to cover the word. The object is to be the 1st player to fill a horizontal, vertical, or diagonal line. There can be numerous variations to the standard play to accommodate different age groups or to emphasize English or Arabic language skills.

More info here...
http://onlineislamicstore.com/a4437.html

name: Game of Knowledge: Spirit of Islam
description:
This board game originated in India some time before the 18th century. There were many versions, each based on different belief systems. This Muslim version is known as the Game of Knowledge. It teaches the player about Islam.

The player of this game embarks on a journey during which he will learn that the upward path of the spiritual seeker is a gradual one. The game starts at the left of the bottom row on the square inscribed Adam, and continues across each successive row to the top row inscribed with the names of the archangels. Each square is filled with an inscription describing one of a hundred different states of man.

More information here...

http://www.moa.ubc.ca/spiritofislam/knowledge/game_of_knowle...

name: Rose Petal Place
description:
A light and simple game for children Ages 4 and up. Each player is a flower. Play cards in various combinations to advance along the board track and pickup teardrops. When everyone has reached the end of the track, count teardrop points. The winner is the player with the highest total.

From the rules:
ROSE-PETAL is trapped and is very unhappy in NASTINA's overgrown weed garden. It's up to the flowers to find her along the trail of teardrops, and save her from this unhappiness with sunshine and tears. But watch out for NASTINA! She'll try to stop you every chance she gets. The flower who cries the most magic tears wins.

Based on the children's toys and animated series Rose Petal Place.

name: Siege
description:
Listed in American Games, #4175. 1976, Military, Board Game.

A typical move-and-capture game, such as Draugths or Checkers. The board represents a castle and a perimeter. Players move along paths that connect spaces together. Capture is by jumping over an adjacent piece to any vacant space beyond and is mandatory. Both players have the same pieces - one King, four Knights and eight pawns. The pieces have a hierarchy where a piece may not capture a more important piece.

One player is the Defender and the other the Attacker. The Defender starts his pieces from the middle of the board whilst the attacker starts on the perimeter. The object is to make the other player resign by eliminating enough pieces that there is no point in continuing.

The rules are extensive with many elaborations, hints and examples of play.

name: Thrift: A Banking Game
description:
Listed in American Games, #4222. 1963, Economic, Board game, a premium for Lincoln Bank.

Thrift is a quick to learn, exciting game of banking. It is educational and challenging. The game is designed to develop and test basic money handling skills. The object of the game is to be the first player to build a bank account of $2,500.

Equipment:


A playing board, located on box cover
A pack of fortune cards
A supply of paper money
A spinner
A playing piece

name: Sonopoly
description:
One of many local variations on the boardgame Monopoly, Sonopoly is based on Sonoma County, California. Produced by Santa Rosa-based Trinity Productions in 1985, it was assembled by Rapid Mounting and Finishing Co. of Burlingame, California.

The mechanics, most rules, board, and themes are mostly the same as Monopoly, but there are some significant differences.

Board and Properties: The properties are all businesses in Sonoma County; there are no railroads or utilities; there are no jail, free-parking, or go-to-jail spaces; there are chance cards, but no community chest or equivalent; all four corners are properties which players can buy and on which they must pay rent; the purchase prices and rent are all different.

Rules: There are coloured monopolies essentially the same as in Monopoly, but in addition, the four corners together make up one monopoly just like properties of one colour. Players build "investments" instead of houses and can build up to 2 on each property. The few non-coloured properties not at the corners are stand-alone properties on which one can build an investment without owning any other properties. Finally, players collect $2,000 not for passing "go" but for passing the West America Bank space (at the location of the go-to-jail space in Monopoly).

Pieces: Money is in demoninations of $20, 50, 100, 500, 1000, and 5000. Each amount has a different business and picture on it. The player pieces are coloured plastic pawns. The investment pieces are not houses and hotels, but coloured wooden cylinders called "barrels" in the rules.
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Trading

name: Bop Baseball
description: In this game of manual dexterity, players attempt to bat a "ball" into scoring locations on a long flat wooden board that can be between 4 to 6 feet long! The game resembles a crude pinball machine. The game also comes with a score pad, a bell, and scoring devices. The box cover states that from 1 to 9 players can play on a team.

name: Colour Shift
description:
Colour Shift is an abstract strategy game for 1 to 6 players.

Players draw and place movement or special event cards in a race to collect the most scoring counters from a random tile board.
mechanics: Hand Management, Modular Board, Open Drafting, Point to Point Movement, Tile Placement

name: Doodads
description:
“I’ll trade you a cabbage and some duct tape for your toddler.”
A game about trading and building for 3 to 5 players.
Learn what ingredients you need to make things. Turn money into ingredients. Turn ingredients into things. Use your things to give you an advantage over your opponents. Learn what things you need to build doodads. Build doodads out of things. Use your doodads to give you an even greater advantage over your opponents. End the game with the most diverse collection of doodads, things, and ingredients.

The game is freely downloadable on the publisher's site:
http://www.invisible-city.com/play/443/Doodads

name: Air Trafic
description: In Air Trafic, a game published at the end of the '70s or early '80s by Nathan, the players manage an air company. he who earns the most money wins the game.

name: Double Game: The Glade of Dreams
description:
The "Double Game" series of books uses a combat and inventory system familiar to many "fighting fantasy" style books. But this one allows two players to play simultaneously (each using a different book of the pair). The books use cross-reference tables to allow the players to interact with each other (usually cooperating) at certain points.

One player player plays Darian, the Master Magician. The other plays the Issel, the Warrior King.
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Dice Rolling, Simultaneous Action Selection, Variable Player Powers

name: Farbstrakt
description:
The game "Farbstrakt" was included in Spielbox 1/91 as part of the "Spiel im Heft/Game in the zine" series.

The board consists of 2 halves of 5x10 grids, which must be layed together so that at least 2 spaces connect the two halves.

The 100 spaces on the board are coloured in one of 5 different colours and show numbers from 0-9. 5 playing pieces in these 5 colours is the only material that is needed for this game.

The game consists of a race between these 5 pieces. The players secretly write down a ranking list before the game begins.

Each player can move any playing piece, and the distance a piece can move is determined by the numbers on the board, where all 5 pieces are standing.

Winner of the game is not the player who reaches the finish line with a playing piece first, but the one who has predicted the ranking of the race the best.
mechanics: Betting and Bluffing, Modular Board, Point to Point Movement

name: Eine wird gewinnen
description:
This game was published in the newspaper "taz" as an addition to the voting of "Kulturhauptstadt 2010" in Germany.

It is a simple yatzee-style dice-rolling game, where 16 different cities compete on being the "Kulturhauptstadt 2010".

name: Carl Yastrzemski Action Baseball
description:
Carl Yastrzemski Action Baseball from Pressman is the official Yastrzemski Baseball game and features and all metal field, automatic umpire and a scoreboard.

Game listing comes from a compilation of games created by the Yahoo Baseball Games Group. A more complete description of the game will be created from information received from members of the group.

name: Centre Rock
description:
A game of territory, defense, and pushing the other guy around! Your foot soldiers will stop at nothing to gain control of The Rock for you, but you must manage shifting alliances, plan ahead while striking now, and catch good fortune to be victorious...

Centre Rock is an abstract strategy game in which 2--4 players vie for control of The Rock. Each player commands a squad consisting of a striker (pikeman), two archers, and two melee units. Movement is based on hexes, and each unit type may attack a particular pattern of surrounding cells. Games take 45--90 minutes.

Centre Rock is also a freely downloadable DIY game. Full rules, game board, and pieces are available for download on the RocketShip Games website along with detailed instructions for constructing your own copy.
categories: Abstract Strategy, Medieval, Miniatures, Print & Play, Renaissance, Wargame

name: Eat at Ralph's
description:
The object of the game is to be the first player to feed all your food to Ralph. On each turn players roll the die and must feed him certain food. A numbered roll (1, 2, or 3) indicates the number of food that he must swallow. If a player rolls "Stuff", he or she can attempt to feed him as much food as he or she wants to attempt. If he regurgitates the food, the player must keep it which may include some that he or she did not feed him. (Ralph is also a common expression for vomiting.)

Dietary note: "Ralph has a sensitive stomach! Please don't feed him anything except the special cardboard food enclosed."

name: King of the Hill
description: King of the Hill is a version of the children's game of War, with a strategic aspect added. Just like the parent game, it uses ordinary playing cards. Players get to choose the cards to be played and the reward for winning. A separate reserve of cards to break ties adds to the strategy. Win as many cards as you can, but remember, only the player who wins the last battle can be King of the Hill!

name: Dragons
description:
Dragons, "The Family Game of Frenzy," is a family-style card game where up to eight players simultaneously attempt to get rid of their deck by playing their cards to sequentially build "dragons."

This game's core mechanic is a type of simultaneous, speed-based card play similar to that used in solitaire. Players have five card slots in front of them, from which they play cards into the center of the table onto piles which comprise dragons made up of first a tail, then the numbers 1-10, and then a head. When players have played a card from one of their slots, they then quickly replace it with one from their deck. Players may play on any dragon stack in the center, which leads to a great deal of frenzy as players try to monitor their own play stacks, keep an eye on the multiple dragon piles that are constantly growing, and try to avoid allowing other players to gain an advantage in building.

Optional rules introduce complexity in scoring, the color sequencing of dragons, battles between players for simultaneous card play, and two-headed or two-tailed dragons. A notable feature of the game is its giant fold-out play mat which includes markings for card play and card slots.

name: The Twilight Zone Game
description: Board game based on the TV show "The Twilight Zone.

name: Rubik's Brain Game
description:
Rubik's Brain Game is more or less a 2-dimensional Mastermind. As in that game, players take turns setting up a pattern which the other player must deduce, with the player making the deduction in the fewest moves winning the game.

In this game, a pattern is a 3x3 grid with each square being one of 6 colors, looking much like the side of a scrambled Rubik's Cube (the pattern is formed with 9 small cubes). On each turn, the guesser can either ask the setter if a given set of three colors are in a given row or column, or can ask if a given space is a specific color. In the former case the colors present and the colors not present are placed in different sections of the board for tracking purposes.

name: Cranium Squawkbox: Lunch Munch
description:
It's time to eat! Lindy the Lunch Lady is cooking up all sorts of fun in her kitchen … like anchovy milkshakes and mashed potato pizza! Her wild menu is sure to have you giggling as you match cards together to create four-course meals. Once you've collected a five-meal feast for Lindy's cafeteria, you win!

Lunch Munch is portable, easy to play, and features an electronic Lunch Lady announcer for a card game unlike any you've played before.

What's in the box?
Includes electronic Squawkbox and 88 illustrated Lunch Munch cards. Requires three AAA batteries (included).

name: Molimba
description: A two player trick taking game in which the objective is to go out first with a two- or one-suited hand of nine cards. Players start with nine randomly dealt cards and two face down "shed" cards between them. Standard no-trump trick-taking rules apply (with aces high) and the loser of the trick exchanges two of his cards (without revealing them) for the two face down cards.

name: Peek-a-boo Rummy
description: A two-player Rummy variant where certain discards force cards in the draw deck to be exposed.

name: The Peter Rabbit Radish Board Game
description:
The Peter Rabbit Radish Board Game

It’s a race around the vegetable garden collecting radishes, carrots, green beans and lettuce, but watch out for grumpy Mr McGregor….if he catches you then you’ll be going to bed with a very empty tummy indeed!
publishers: Crown & Andrews Ltd., Paul Lamond Games Ltd

name: Ave Caesar: Kurs 1
description:
UNRELEASED GAME



Note that all details of this game are preliminary. This game has not been released, and since its announced release date has long since passed, this game might never be released. This listing serves as a historical record; you are invited to submit corrections or update this section if additional information comes to light.




Ave Caesar: Kurs 1 (Course 1) will include a double-sided board with two new tracks, six horsecarts, six coins and 144 cards. The art is by Eckhard Freytag and Ingrid Berner.

Expands:

Ave Caesar

name: Du bist der Größte, kleiner Rabe
description:
You are the Biggest, Little Raven! All the forest friends of little Raven race from all edges of the forest to little Raven's nest in the meadow. Each team has three animals and little Raven is the judge. The first team member to reach the center gets a piece of the cake from little Raven in its nest. Naturally he or she takes the largest piece. And once the pieces are distributed, little Raven determines which crew won.
An exciting game for color learning.
Contents: game board, 12 play figures, 1 little Raven, 1 Raven nest, 8 pieces of cake of different sizes, 2 color cubes, and rules.
Ages 4 and up.

name: Miracles and Pitfalls
description:
In Miracles and Pitfalls up to six players race around the board from the Start space to the Finish space, answering Bible questions from one of four different categories (Bible Characters, Places, Objects, and Fill in the Blanks). A player must correctly answer a question before having the opportunity to roll the die to move forward. Most of the spaces on the board correspond to one of the four categories, but some spaces allow a player to choose which category they want to answer a question from. Some spaces require a player to draw a "Miracle" card which will give the player some benefit like skipping ahead on the board, while other spaces require the player to draw a "Pitfall" card. These cards have negative effects like, for example, causing a player to lose a turn. There are spaces that allow players to take shortcuts along the path and other spaces that require a player to take a longer detour. Finally, there are slide spaces which allow a player to slide forward or backward one space to get to a category space that might make it easier for the player to answer the question. The box includes 800 questions, with 4 questions per card.

Ages 5 and up.

name: Colossal Fossil Fight
description: In Colossal Fossil Fight, each of the two players use a dinosaur to pick up bones from the bone yard and place them into their den. There are three types of bones (legs, ribs, and skulls) which are worth one, three, and five points, respectively. Once all the bones are removed from the bone yard, the player with the most bone points in their den is the winner.

name: Crime Busters: Space Precinct
description:
Gerry Anderson's Space Precinct Crime Busters Board Game!

Each player is issued with a case to solve. By moving around Demeter City in their Police Cruisers players must gather evidence and locate and apprehend their suspect.

Players move by spinner or communication cards. Players move to relevant crime scenes to collect evidence. Once the player has collected four evidence tokens (including the three specific ones for their case they can attempt to apprehend the suspect.

To apprehend the player trades unwanted evidence to look at a suspect card.

Once apprehend then its back to the Station to win the game

name: American Dream Game
description:
From the back of the box:

The American quest for fame and fortune. Four different levels of fun to choose from. A real American Made Game. Find security, peace of mind, wealth. Set goals and plan strategies.

name: Wilde Horde
description:
At the dawn of time, man emerged from the cave and wanted something to do.

So they invented a sport: Rockball. The rules of this game are long lost to the passing years, but you can recreate the thrill and excitement of being a Rockball team manager. Recruit athletes with bribes – bones, rocks, sticks and meat – but draft carefully; only the smart leader will build the best team.

name: Mixed Pickles
description:
Simple word game in which players create silly sentences from phrases on cards. Example:

I'm always in for

Hunting buffalo

At a wedding

Leading to outrageous fun at the turn of the century.

name: Groeninghe Velt 1302 Guldensporenslag
description: The Flemish have beaten the French in a battle that took place on 11 July 1302 in the neighborhood of Kortrijk (Belgium). Groeninghe Velt brings you back to the time of crossbows, cavalry and man to man fights.
mechanics: Campaign / Battle Card Driven, Hexagon Grid, Point to Point Movement, Simulation

name: Foster's Home For Imaginary Friends Corridor Chaos Board Game
description:
from back of game "Help Mac and Blooregard find 5 imaginary friends within the winding halls of Madame Foster's Mansion! Flip hallway tiles to reveal hidden characters. The first player to reach 5 imaginary friends wins!"
Contents= 1 game board, 2 movers, 16 path tiles, 4 command tiles, 15 imaginary friend cards, 1 die, instructional sheet.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Modular Board, Tile Placement

name: Game of War at Sea or "Don't Give Up the Ship"
description:
Published at the time of the Spanish-American War, players move their ships across a checkerboard pattern covering the Gulf of Mexico, Carribean, the coast of Central America, and the U.S. Atlantic seaboard. The goal is to sweep the opponent's navy from the sea.

Game comes with 12 Battleships and 12 Torpedo Boats.

name: Free for All
description:
This is a very simple DTP card game, suitable from 2 to 5 players, Ages 10 and up, regarding a group of prison inmates transferred from one penal colony to another. During the transit, the convoy may be assaulted by other criminals trying to free their comrades, but it may even be defended by more police forces.
Each player may take the role of one of these two colliding factions, changing it from one turn to the other, trying to get as many convoys as he can for winning the game.
With a simple simultaneous action system, players try to get the more convoy cards they can, choosing wisely when to play the special cards that consent to win the hand without fight.

Components
1 deck of 16 convoy cards
1 deck of 47 action cards
One coin (not provided) for each player

Available as print & play through wargamedownloads.com

name: Saving Primate Brian
description:
This is a simple card game for 2 to 4 players, Ages 7 and up, about Brian, an almost extinct Orango, that needs food to survive.
The aim of the game is to save 3 "Brians" (orangutan) from extinction, giving him the food he needs to survive. This is done by a simple draw/discard cards system, with several nuisances you may give to your opponents.
Made especially for children, the game is anyway good for all the family, with a small but important ecological message on it, as it is important to save the "real" Brians in our world

Components
1 deck of 63 cards

Available as print & play through wargamedownloads.com
Italian version, called "Salviamo il primate Brian" Available as print & play through arima.it

name: Party & Co Expansion
description:
This is an expansion for Party & Co. Comes with 200 new cards (1000 new challenges).

Expands:

Party & Co
publishers: Diset S. A., Nordic Games GmbH

name: Cech zlodějů
description:
Thieves Guild (= Cech zlodějů) is a fast-paced card game where you become a thief among thieves. The "winner" is the player who is most successful in robbing the others. You can't trust anyone here, the police are corrupt and the other well-known companies in town never sleep either. They are constantly watching you and will use every opportunity to get your money back, even with interest. For these cases, it is always useful to have a bribe or a well-guarded safe in your pocket.

In each round, a player starts by buying cards. He can buy one or more cards from the supply pack, for which he pays with his gold. The first card costs one gold, if the player wants more cards, it is always more expensive. Gold used to buy cards creates a bank next to the supply deck. It is empty at the beginning of the game. If the card says "remove" the gold, it means to put it in the bank. After buying the cards, the player goes to loot.

During the Loot phase, a player rolls the dice twice. The first roll determines how many gold he can loot that round. If no opponent reacts to this throw, the player throws a second time. The second roll determines who gets robbed that turn. The number of points rolled is the distance of the opponent to be robbed. The player whose turn it is decides whether to count to the left or to the right. If the roll equals the number of players, the roller, he cannot rob anyone.

The game ends when one player loses all their gold. The player with the most gold wins.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Open Drafting, Take That

name: Little Amadeus Maestro
description:
The players are assigned the roles of Mozart, his sister Nannerl, Joseph Haydn, and Ludwig van Beethoven and must round up an orchestra able to play a work of Mozart. Everybody tries to gather the required musicians to be able to give a concert. If a player is able to successfully conduct a concert, victory points are awarded. If, however, musicians remain unemployed throughout the game, there will be a penalty...

Contains:
- 46 musician cards
- 10 conductor cards
- 4 agents desks
- 14 ovation cards
- 1 Devilius
- 4 playing pieces
- 1 game board
- 1 music compact disc containing works of Mozart arranged especially for children

Revised version of:

Maestro

name: Orbito
description:
Subtitled: *The Far Out Strategy Game*
"Blast Off Through the Orbiting Track to a Galaxy of Fun in this Exciting Space Race Game"

Published 1977 by Israel's Orda Industries, Orbito features an interesting board with a rotating ring, a bunch of stumps to hold the spaceship pegs, and 4 colored 'space station' areas in each of the 4 corners. Additional components are plastic 'spaceships', 4 each of 4 colors, and a 6-sided die.

Players attempt to move all their spaceships from his or her space station, through the launching track, and across the board to the diagonally opposite station. Players take turns rolling a 6-sided die then rotating the center ring and moving 1 piece the number shown on the die. The first player to get all his/her ships to the other side wins.

Presumed to be out of print.

name: Photo Trivia: Potpourri Game
description:
Object: Players try to win each card by looking at the photo and correctly answering a question from that card. The player who collects the most cards is the winner.

You can play all the questions or just a few. And because no game board or score pad is needed, you can play anywhere! Play at home, at parties, or while traveling.

Number of players: Two or more, individually or in teams.

Approximate Playing Time: 10 minutes to a whole evening.

Equipment: Two decks of Photo Trivia cards - 107 photos, 642 questions and answers, rules.

The Potpourri Game has something for everyone!

name: Diversion 7
description:
Players try to peg out by rolling dice combinations that match the different lanes on the wooden, cribbage-like pegging board. For instance, the peg in your 6 lane moves one space closer to home with every 6 you have rolled on the dice. Once you peg out on a given lane, you now score victory points every time you roll that number. Opportunities exist to bump your opponent back by landing on him, or to have your roll count double, depending on your peg position.

But first, each time you roll the dice, you have to set aside any pair of dice that add up to seven! If the first throw doesn't look good enough, you may take one re-roll.

name: What If?
description: What If? is a fun question and answer game designed by Diane Rogers and dated 1968. What If is the hypothetical question game for teens and adults. Game comes with a couple of pamphlets with questions to be asked and a set of rules on how to play the game rules. The game box is 8-1/4 x 10-1/4 x 1-1/2.

name: Flesh
description: Game originally published in the British comic book 2000 AD, issues #8-11. Based on the comic Flesh were rangers from the future travel in time to kill dinosaurs for meat.
categories: Animals, Bluffing, Card Game, Comic Book / Strip, Prehistoric, Science Fiction

name: Dragon War: Jurassic Valley Set
description:
This expansion adds 9 cards that form a valley of lost dinosaurs that players will have to pass through on their way to claiming the Dragon Throne.

Expansion to Dragon War
categories: Dice, Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy, Fighting
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Roll / Spin and Move, Variable Player Powers

name: Sally the Sunflower
description:
An unusual game where players take turns trying to place magnetic bees onto magnetic spots on the face of Sally the sunflower. If the polarity is correct the bee sticks, if not Sally turns her head away.

From the manufacturer:
"Will Sally turn her face away or let your bumblebees land? Sally the Sunflower shows children the wonder of magnets all through the fun of play! Watch their enjoyment as they try to make a positive connection by landing their bumblebees onto Sally's face! The first to get all their bumblebees onto Sally's face wins!"

name: Ranko
description:
From the Directions:
RANKO is a game for 2,3, or 4 players using a deck of 48 cards, each having a numeral. Each RANKO player is dealt 8 cards which he must place in a rack in the order dealt. Then, by replacing various cards in his rack he tries to get his cards ranked so that the numbers represented on the cards are in increasing order from front to rear.

Four different games are possible since there are four different decks of cards:
(a) Pink cards have numerals 1 to 48 in standard form: 1, 2, 3, 4,..., 46, 47, 48.
(b) Blue cards have numerals 1 to 48 in non-standard form: (36/36), (2^3/2^2), (9/3),..., (7^2-2), (2^4x3).
(c) Yellow cards have numerals from 1 to 48 in base five:
1five, 2five, 3five,..., 142five, 143five.
(d) White cards have numerals for the multiples of 4 from 4 to 192: 4, 8, 12, 16,..., 184, 188, 192."

name: Brief 'n' Brisk Pro Basketball
description:
Fast-Action Games created many "quick-play" sports simulations where the outcome of a contest could be decided with just one or two dice rolls. These games made it easy to play an entire series of games in a matter of just a few minutes.

This game covers professional basketball. Like all of the team sports games in this line, a few simple numbers, devised from team statistics, enable the player to recreate an entire season in a short period of time.

Includes NBA, BBA, ABA, NBL, ABL, WPBT, and PBLA and NPBL leagues.

Fast-Action Game Description
PROFESSIONAL BRIEF ’N’ BRISK BASKETBALL (Revised Edition)
This realistic PRO HOOPS game includes over 1,000 teams:

EVERY NBA and BAA team since 1946!
EVERY ABA team (1967 thru 1976)!
EVERY NBL team (1937 thru 1949)!
ABL teams (1936 thru 1946)!
More ABL teams (1961 thry 1963)!
And More!!


Recreate entire seasons and see if you can lead your FAVORITE team to victory! Or play the greats against one another —- imagine the 1985-86 BOSTON CELTICS against the 1949-50 MINNEAPOLIS LAKERS! Stage DREAM TOURNAMENTS to determine the GREATEST team of ALL TIME!!
Complete game costs only $12 postpaid

name: Chards
description:
A game that combines Chess and cards.

This is how it is described at the game's website:
Chards TM uses a deck of 52 cards (Chards) with the normal suits: Hearts, Spades, Diamonds, and Clubs. Each player selects a favorite suit, places their King on the board and begins to play. Chards are added to the board during play anywhere on the board so the playing field—and challenge—is always changing.

Each Turn - Players do three things on their turn: Move a Chard, Turn (twist) a Chard, and Place a Chard from their stockpile. It's FUN! ... and Easy!

Chess characters include Kings, Queens, Bishops, Knights, Rooks and Pawns.

Card characters include Jacks and Jokers and Dukes (ever played with a deuce in cards?). Chards TM even has Archers and Wizards to give the game a special twist. And it’s the twists in the game that make it exciting!

There are no stalemates in Chards TM. Surprises are common so winners often come from behind. Are you clever or lucky? It takes a bit of both to win at Chards TM. That’s what makes it FUN!

Whether it’s family fun or party entertainment, Chards TM is a game that players want to play again and again. The FUN is enjoyed by all ages, be they adults or teens or kids. Have a tournament. Form a club. Use Chards TM as a fund raising event.

Most of all – Chards TM is a great way to have FUN!

name: Mariposa
description:
Mariposa is a children´s game about butterflies. In this tile laying game players form butterflies on flowers with 4 tiles. Players try to be the first to build four of these and place their butterflies on them - thereby winning the game.

Ages 5 and up. Released: Essen 2007.

name: Deluxe Geodyssey
description:
This game is geared for kids 8+ and is annotated as "Columbus Approved" with a photo of Christopher Columbus himself. It has to be right, it has his photo... No matter...

The game is a tile laying game where each square represents an area of Earth. The tiles are shuffled face down. Each player gets a 5 tiles to start with as his or her hand. A tile from the remaining tiles is laid face up as the starting tile. if on your turn you can't put a tile down, then you take a new one. First one to get rid of all their tiles wins. You can challenge a player on his or her turn about the placement of their tile; if the challenger loses the challenge, he or she loses the turn and must also take a tile. If the challenged player loses, the he or she retrieves the placed tile and takes another.

name: Drew Pearson's Predict-a-Word
description:
Drew Pearson was a radio personality in the 1940s United States who had a segment on his show where he predicted upcoming events in politics and current affairs. This game was apparently created to market the show through the public's association of Drew Pearson with predictions.

The game is played by first spinning a spinner to decide which letter of the alphabet will go in the top left corner of a 5x5 square grid. The players then, in turn, call a letter to fill in the rest of the grid, one letter at a time. Each player has their own grid, and places the called letter on their grid without seeing where the calling player has placed theirs. Hence the 'prediction' - players must 'predict' what word the calling player is trying to build in order to know where to place the letters being called.

The game includes a rule booklet including a list of helpful words, a spinner, and a pad of blank 5x5 charts.

name: Jogo da Pescaria
description:
From the publisher: "On this superfun lake you'll catch fishes of all sizes. The largeer fishes worth 3 or 5 points each and the smaller ones 1 or 2 points There are also the fishbones that are worthless, they are there just to hinder your fishing. So you'll need a bit of luck to catch the better fishes before the other player. Who get more points at the end is the winner!"

This is a cute little game for the small kids (ages 4 to 8), where two players race to catch the most fish but also the bigger fishes. When all the fishes are caught, players add their points, who got the most wins, simple as that!

name: !Blitzkrieg¡
description:
Juego de iniciación al wargame ambientado en la segunda guerra mundial.Incluye reglas,tablero de 40x90 cm y 40 fichas.

Game initiation wargame of WWII.Contain one map 40x90 cm, rulebook, and 40 counters.

name: Raging Champions
description:
Do you have what it takes to coach a Raging Champion to the final match and win?

Choose your characters and the tournament begins... Watch your Raging Champions compete one-on-one against fierce contenders in the only bracket-formatted board game available.

Use your Appeal Chips to stay out of trouble and beware of the ejection card... Draw it and one of your Raging Champions is out of the tournament. As you battle and advance towards the final match, the excitement builds and coaches choose favorites - watch out because these guys are tough to beat.

name: Bubble & Squeak!
description:
Described on the box as a "frantic action card game where the faster squeaker wins!"

There are 6 sets of 4 cards. each set in a differn't colour. There are also 5 rubber squeaky mice. The objective being to collect a set of cards and squeak the rubber mouse.
categories: Action / Dexterity, Animals, Card Game, Children's Game

name: Geheimnis der Detektive
description:
A gang of robbers has stolen some valuable goods last night. This loot is still in town, but there is no relying on the police. So the players - as detectives (private eyes) - are appointed to find the loot.

The game uses a special movement system regarding the famous German pub game "Knobeln". It is all about bluffing and hunting for the best cards. Sudden events can alter the personal strategy. Each player gets 5 small (movement) sticks. Acting simultaneously with his neighbor both hide a certain number of sticks in their hands, then open their hands and count up the total amount. Players may move if both hands show different numbers of sticks and the total amount does not equal 5; if you end on a loot slide check it (value 0 - 4) & keep it. If a player lands on another player, it offers you an opportunity to steal. If the stick-count equals 5 players add a barrier, and an equal number of sticks held by each player forces them back to the starting point, and they draw an event card.
mechanics: Betting and Bluffing, Open Drafting, Rock-Paper-Scissors, Simultaneous Action Selection

name: Moby Dicks Freunde
description:
Moby Dicks Freunde is played on a board with 8 x 10 rhombs. Every line of the rhomb shows a number between 1 and 6. 8 dice and 8 whales are the game components.

Each player has 4 whales, who are placed on the first 4 rhomb edges to the right. Each turn, 5-8 dice are thrown. Whales can move to adjacent rhomb edges, when the die on the board corresponds to one of the die numbers.

A restriction is that the 4 whales of a player must always form a herd, that is they must always be connected to each other.

Moving the whales on the side where the opposing herd stays is allowed, but only, if they are not blocked by such moves. Thus, a certain amount of cooperative play is requested!

Winner of the game is the player whose herd reaches the opposing side of the board first.

(Karin and Reinhold Wittig are named for the copyright of the game rules. The game is by Reinhold Wittig alone, though).
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Dice Rolling, Pattern Building

name: Baseball
description:
This is a loose simulation of baseball for two players, designed for the piecepack. There’s plenty of luck involved, but some of the choices managers face in real life are represented here, such as how to pitch to certain batters, when to change your pitcher, and whether or not to go for that extra base. You’ll need a basic familiarity with the sport to play this game, as baseball rules are not outlined much here.

The game is five innings, though extra innings may be necessary. Optional rules are included.

name: Tomtespelet
description:
Two game variants:
Tomtespelet and "Tomten and Trolls" (Tomten are Swedish dwarfs). Both with elements of Checkers and Focus.

Produced by Ravensburger with nice components, though the title giving Tomtespelet is totally broken as far as I recall (probably due to a rule error).

name: Church Ball: The Game
description: Church Ball The Game is a game for two players or two teams based on the LDS movie of the same name. Players attempt to score baskets by rolling the dice and using cards which modify the dice rolls.

name: Catholic-opoly
description:
A Catholic variant of Monopoly. Players compete to build churches, do good works, and manage their money.

From the publisher: Catholic-opoly is a creative and imaginative Catholic board game based on the principles and history of the Catholic faith. The goal of this game is to build as many churches and cathedrals as possible in order to “help spread the word of the Lord”. Players can learn about the history and practices of the Catholic church and read scriptures related to Biblical locations as they move about the board. In addition, the game addresses financial management and community service as well.
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Trading

name: Junior Combination Games
description: This game by Milton Bradley copyrighted 1905 features a number of table games all combined in the same box. Included are India, Johny Jumps, Railroad Game, Puss in the Corner, Fortune Telling, Checkers, Covering the Pig, Steeplechase, Bicycle race, Hop, American Corners and Yacht Race. Game came with numerous Bits and pieces used as playing pieces for any of the games you might want to play.

name: Ísland: spurningaspil
description:
Ísland - spurningaspil (Iceland) is basically a trivia game with some economic traits, where you travel around Iceland and along the way you can buy and sell properties and build motels and hotels on those properties. Other players pay rent when they land on a property belonging to others.

If you land on a question spot, you have ten seconds to answer the question (six categories), getting a reward if answered correctly, or paying a penalty (money or doing something silly) if getting the answer wrong. Players decide for how long they play, whether for a set period of time or as long it takes to eliminate all the others.

name: Cooperation: The wealth of Nations Game
description:
COOPERATION: The Wealth of Nations Game is a boardgame simulating economic systems. It includes four different variants of different skill levels based on different economic systems. BARTER is the beginners' game, MAJORITY RULE is the socialist game, MAKING MONEY is the capitalist game, and AUTONOMY is the expert tournament game.

The game plays up to six players. Each player manages cities. The object of a game is to obtain basic resources for each city while employing the fewest people . Players receive points for each different resource they obtain and bonus points for citizens at leisure.

AUTONOMY simulates a futuristic possible economic system that would produce wealth for everyone with a minimum of work.

The game is based on Information Chain Theory.

In addition to existing as a boardgame, this game is downloadable as an electronic game from the publishers' website.
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Cooperative Game, Simulation, Stock Holding, Team-Based Game, Trading

name: 5.56mm
description:
25/28mm modern skirmish system. Rules cover infantry and vehicles. Players are intended to use about a squad each.

The game relies on a card based activation system - each character is assigned a card and activates when it is drawn. Elite characters get a second card but receive fewer actions when it comes up.

Task rolls are done with a single six-sided die and generally scale by distance. Better trained characters receive a larger bonus to their tests.

Damage is an opposed roll (damage versus strength) and can inflict death or one of several wound states. Wounds reduce movement and penalize a character on skill tests.

The morale rules are tucked away in the back of the rules, but boil down to checking morale for certain casualty-based triggers.

The rulebook does not provide a points or scenario system, though there is a system for generating squads. Wargames Journal has published at least one scenario for the game as a free PDF download.

name: Śląsk 1939
description: Slask 1939 (Silesia 1939) depicts the battle taking part in southwestern Poland during the 1939 invasion.

name: Efni
description:
The game of Efni uses Icehouse pieces and (a subset of) a Fluxx-deck.

The Fluxx-cards are shuffled and dealt, face-down, to form a playing board. Icehouse pieces are distributed over the play area (exact distribution depends on the number of players). Players take turns to move and reveal cards.

The object is to capture sets of cards by occupying those cards with your own pieces. Points are scored for the number of Goals and Keepers captured with goals worth ten times the keepers.

name: Giant Freaking Worms!
description:
What better way to terraform a planet than using giant freaking worms to do it for you? They’re big, efficient and pretty dumb too. Sure, it’s kinda gross that they leave behind entire ecosystems as their doodie, but let’s see you chew up rocks and squirt out an island, bucko.

Equipment:

* 3 six-sided dice for each player (representing the players' worms)
* A whole bunch of Magic: The Gathering land cards

Each player takes turns moving his worms around a board made up of Magic: the Gathering land cards, dropping land cards or destroying land cards in the process. The first player to place ten of one kind of land on the field wins. Alternatively, the first player to lose a worm or to run out of one type of land card in his decks loses.

name: Abgezockt!
description:
"Abgezockt!" ("Ripped off!") is a push-your-luck dice game to be the first to get 6000 points. This sounds easier than it is. Already the first die roll is tricky, as the special die can destroy your plans. If you are allowed to continue rolling, only that roll counts, or do you have to give all your points to another player?

Each further roll you need to balance the risk between either making even more points or losing them all. But attention! Getting too many points envokes your fellow players' envy.

There is also the "Chance to rip off" or the action card "fieser Hund" ("vicious dog"). With these, any player can get points quickly. But no risk, no fun, so you try to get the maximal points each time, as this is the only way to get the prescious action cards.

The game includes 6 six-sided dice, a special "action" dice, pencils, cards, scoring pad, dice cup, rules and rules synopsis cards.
categories: Animals, Card Game, Dice, Party Game
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Hand Management, Push Your Luck, Re-rolling and Locking, Take That

name: Wolf and Sheep
description:
Wolves want to eat sheep.
Sheep want to get home safely to their pen.

The two wolves are very free in their movements to capture the sheep. Though they are limited in mobility, the sheep make up for it in numbers (18) Players try to make the best use of their different abilities and goals. Often games are played in pairs with players switching roles for the second game.

Components: Game board, Rules, 18 sheep markers, 2 wolf markers

name: Color Checkers
description:
Color Checkers "Finally, a game more challenging than checkers but easier than chess"

There are two primary team colors - white and black. On one side, the crown side, the color is solid white or black. On the other side there are four different colors - blue, red, green, and yellow. There are four single colored, six bi-colored, and two quad-colored checkers for each team.

The 24 pieces are set up just as in regular Checkers. The object of the game is also the same: to eliminate your opponent's men by jumping over them. To do so, your checker must have the same color on it as the one you are jumping. When you reach the opposite side of the board, you turn your checker over to the solid side - black or white. Then, like regular checkers, you can move backwards or forwards. It can now jump or be jumped by any of your opponent's checkers. In case of a stalemate, the last player to move wins.

A second way to play is more advanced. You simply jump over your own man in order to jump your opponent's man as long as all have a like color.

name: Blurt! Travel Edition
description:
From the back of the box:

"Players take turns reading a simple definition aloud, while others Blurt out guesses in a hilarious race for the right word...

"The Travel Edition of Blurt! includes: 300 Blurt! definitions on 50 cards, card sleeve, instructions, custom scoreboard, and 4 scoring pegs."

This version includes rules for a junior version of the game, suitable for Ages 7 - 9.
publishers: Educational Insights, Keys Publishing, Patch Products

name: One-O-Five
description: One-O-Five is a simple, fast moving children's game played with five dice each. Each player in turn rolls their dice and sets aside those showing their target number. The objective is to roll and set aside all five dice before moving onto their next target number. Target numbers are 1s up to 6s. Once all five dice show the player's target number they roll all five dice again, aiming for and setting aside the next number in the sequence. The winner is the player who rolls all six sets of five identical numbers (up to 6s).

name: Shaken Up
description:
From the Babooshik Website
Shaken Up!™
The Intoxicating Dice Game

Get the party rolling! Shake up your next shindig with this push-your-luck dice game. Roll combos and "make drinks" to score, but watch out — one of your friends might steal it all! How’s that for a little controversy cocktail?

Shaken Up is the perfect mixer. Shake the ‘dice cubes’ high and low in the exquisite stainless steel martini shaker. If you make 2-pairs, full-houses, or 4-of-a-kind you can add scoring chips to the pot, but to bank those chips you’ll have to decide if you’re a martini or a margarita drinker and then make your drink. Feeling lucky? Try to tie-one-on or roll the garnish parade to scoop the pot.

Game Components:

Real Cocktail Shaker Container (game stores inside)
Shaker Cup
5 Cocktail Dice
3 Combo Coasters
6 Drink Maker Markers
42 Scoring Chips
Rules

name: Blitzstreig
description:
An abstract strategy game using metal figures or card discs representing aircraft, missiles, tanks, field guns, and different infantry troops. The gameboard has a grid of squares, on which each piece moves one square per turn.

The box describes it as a game of 'War Chess'. Each type of piece has a different range of pieces that it can take (by moving on to its square, as in Chess), and which pieces can take it.

Produced in New Zealand. Stated to be 'Ages 8 and up'.

name: Igloo
description:
Igloo is a turn-based Icehouse game for 2 players (or 2 teams) which can be played on any flat, stable surface. The game uses a standard set of Icehouse pieces and is set up in a similar manner, with the pieces starting out in stash zones that are not part of the playing field. Each player plays a single piece during each turn. The game ends after all pieces have been played.

Each player controls 2 sets of pyramids. However, only one set of pyramids will be worth points at the end of the game. The other set are decoys. Trying to figure out which is which, from the player's style of play and skill at bluffing, adds a level of intrigue to the game.

The complete rules are available at Wunderland.com.

name: Wordbattle
description:
This is a word game that can be played with any number of players.

It is composed of three dice with letters and one die with numbers - there are four letters or numbers with their own color on each side of the die.

Once the dice are rolled, in the allotted time (3 minutes), players try to make a word with the twelve visible letters . Points are given with each letter of the word receiving the value of its like-colored number. In addition to basic 3-6 letter words, the scorecard rewards bonuses if the player can come up with an animal, a name of a town, a word that is 7+ letters, and a word that is composed solely of one color.

A game lasts eight rolls of the dice, with one category on the scorecard being completed with each roll. The player with the highest score at the end wins.

name: Supervillain University
description:
(From the publisher's website):

Supervillain University is a disturbingly fun card game from Alleged Enterprises for up to 6 players. In it, you take on the role of a senior at SVU, bent on completing a series of Secret Agendas that will be culmination of all your hard work and launch you into the world as a card-carrying Junior Supervillain In Training. The only problem? You have a bunch of classmates (read: enemies) who are hell-bent on stopping you and beating you at your own game. With elements of resource-gathering, roleplaying and fast-paced screwing over of all those who oppose you, there’s truly something for everyone. Provided, of course, that “everyone” enjoys backstabbing, conniving and The Wrong.

There are two main phases to the game. In the resource-gathering phase, one player (the rotating TA) reveals an Opportunity that might present itself on a typical day at Supervillain University. All other players will quickly respond, in secret, with their chosen Evil Deed. The TA collects these played actions, reveals them and determines (based on whatever utterly subjective criteria he or she deems fit) which one is the winner. The player with the winning Evil Deed for the round now collects critical resources needed to complete the all-important Secret Agenda in Phase Two.

After collecting sufficient resources, a player may reveal their Secret Agenda – a truly nefarious scheme guaranteed to bring the world to its knees. If the player can survive a flurry of attempts by the other players to sabotage their Secret Agenda, he or she will collect valuable "points." After collecting an arbitrary number of "points," the winning player may then lord his or her mastery over the other losers playing the game.

name: Smurfspelet
description:
Free Smurfan from Gargamels nest. Before enter Gargamels house you need to collect gammelsmurfen, the magic potion and the puppet. Your journey will take you through the forest. But be aware about Gargamels cat Azrael who will try to catch you.

Content:

1 board game
24 cards
4 playing counter
7 surprise cards
dice
rules
categories: Comic Book / Strip, Dice, Movies / TV / Radio theme

name: Pyramid Cards
description: This is a bidding and trick-taking card game. The deck has 5 suits numbered 2 through 12, along with 2 wild cards. It's unusual in that there are rules for playing in 2 or 3 partnerships, like Bridge, along with rules for playing as singles, like Hearts. Along with the deck, the game was sold with a big score pad.

name: Flying Saucers
description:
Flying Saucers is an abstract strategy game that is similar to a four-player Checkers variant. The goal is to capture enemy saucers and be the last player remaining on the board. Players each control 12 discs that represent flying saucers which can move forward either via a straight line or on the diagonal. Once a piece reaches the opposite end of the board it becomes a "Super Saucer" which can move in any direction. Enemy saucers are captured by getting jumped.

The game rules include several variants that can be played on the base game.

From the publisher: Flying Saucers is an exciting new space age game in which each player commands his own private squadron of flying saucers. This game is based on the strange flying saucers which many people say they have seen streaking across the skies. As you play the game of Flying Saucers, you may imagine yourself on a trip through space to a distant star - Challenged each light-year of the way by squadrons of enemy flying saucers, that will swarm about you and try to capture you before you can capture them.

name: You Don't Have More Cows!
description:
From the publisher, "Enjoy three quick-playing card games for young children through adults. Trade, bluff and press your luck to collect the animals you need and score the most points."

Three games in one. New versions of: Spades, Black Jack, and Rummy with a farming theme that young children should enjoy.

name: Japanese Task Force 2: Carrier Battles in the Pacific, 1944
description:
Blind system carrier warfare in Pacific Ocean using inverted counters and dummies.

The designer of this game is " Easy & Exciting Game (EEG) wargame design coterie".
publishers: Easy & Exciting Game, Kokusai-Tsushin Co., Ltd. (国際通信社)

name: Pocky Shock
description: The game is shaped like a box of Pocky, a favorite snack in Japan. Two of the Pockys in the box are spring-loaded and pulling them will cause all of the Pockys to fly out. Players take turns pulling Pockys; if you pull one of the spring-loaded ones, you lose.

name: Playground Commandos
description:
Playground Commandos was an entry in the 2002 Unequal Forces Game Design Competition. The game can consist of the following materials:

• 1 8x8 board (with the central 2x2 area marked)
• 4 Black discs (representing Skateboards)
• 8 Red discs (representing Pogo sticks)
• 6 Coins (representing Trashcans)

This game can be played with the contents of a standard Checker set with the addition of the coins.

name: Compost Gin
description: This is a rummy variant with a composting theme. Players begin with a hand, then draw and discard each turn until they have collected a compost set. The cards describe various elements of composting (vegetation, weather, composting processes, etc.). Each card has a point value from -10 to +15. The winner is the first person to reach 200 points.

name: Crypto
description:
One of the lesser known board-/card games from the Dujardin publisher.

Name heirs from the shortcuts depicted on the cards showing the plate numbers from the French districts of the time edited.

Game consists of 96 cards, 90 of them showing the shortcuts and are numbered from 1 - 90 also. 6 cards show a "Fakir".

Rules for three different games to play are submitted with the game.

Main game is "Crypto-90", where you have to lay out your 9 pre-dealt cards in ascending order from left to right.
They are laid out per 8 one at a time, from left to right, and the 9th card is kept secret in your hand.
Then you try to be the first to achieve your above mentioned goal.
This, in fact, is a RACKO-clone, but it differs by the fact that all but one of the cards are open to view, and the clever use of the "FAKIR", with whom you can hinder heavily the opponents gameplay.
Game ends after the pack is used up or if anybody gets his street of cards.
Calculating winning points is clever, you can get bonuses among others by laying out only odd or even numbers and for unused FAKIRS.

For the second game, a map of France is provided with the countries' districts. Aim of the game is to lay out your cards according to districts clinging together.
This way you have an educational effect in order to learn the French districts and where they are situated.

Third game is a variant to get rid of your cards as fast as possible.

Very stylish game components: Top quality cardboard box insert for all the gaming stuff, and every player gets a coloured felt mat to lay out his thick, linen finish cards, and even the two card stacks get their own felt mat.

A fun game for the whole family, even by modern standards.
mechanics: Open Drafting, Set Collection, Team-Based Game

name: Jogo da Centopéia
description: From the Publisher: "In this race, the centipedes moves when a color die is rolled. According to the color on the die, the pieces that are behind are placed ahead of the centipede's head. Sometimes you'll have to detour from a little bush that may be placed in your way by another player. First player to get his centipede to cross the finish line is the winner.

name: Landslide!
description:
This is an auction-based roll-and-move election game that adds party and platform-based strategy.

To start the game, prevailing public opinion is rolled (6- Democrat, 7 Independent, 8+ Republican on 2D6). In addition, each player chooses one of five alignments (moderate or conservative Republican, Independent, moderate or liberal Democrat), and secretly chooses up to 6 of the 15 available issues. The 30 issue tiles are shuffled and 3 placed randomly on each side of the board (region): North, East, South and West. The track around the board has a variety of plus or minus spaces, but six out of 10 spaces on each side are blank and trigger auctions.

The player landing on the space can put any unclaimed state in his current region up for auction. Bids are secret and paid in Political Capital (PC), the game’s currency, and players pay their bids whether they win or lose the auction! After their bids are revealed, they are modified by regional issue matches (1/3 = 5 PC; 2/3 = 10 PC; 3/3 = 20 PC) and any card bonuses. Finally, all players roll dice that depend on their affiliations and the state’s preference. (A pink state gives 3 extra D6 to a moderate democrat, 2D6 to a liberal democrat, 1D6 to an Independent, and nothing to Republicans.) The highest total then wins the auction.

While issues help in some states, taking fewer stands allows a player to collect more PC for each circuit of the board. As soon as a Republican and Democratic candidate reach 5 states with 50+ electoral votes, they win the party nomination, and other players in the party either drop out or become independents. Three scenarios are available: full campaign to electoral vote majority; most electoral votes after one time through the Momentum card deck; or a short game won by the first player to win at least one state in every region with at least 50 electoral votes.
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Roll / Spin and Move, Voting

name: Star Trek: Insurrection – Son'a Ambush Adventure
description:
This game was packaged with issue #46 (February 1999) of Inquest Gamer Magazine (the first issue after being renamed from just Inquest Magazine), and it is based on the movie Star Trek: Insurrection. Although it is designed for solo play, it allows a second player to control the Son'a.

You play as the crew of the Enterprise-E, and your goal is to guide the Ba'ku to safety. Inhibiting your progress are the Son'a and their drones which attempt to tag the Ba'ku, thus removing them from the board. You win the game if at least one of the Ba'ku makes it to safety. Combat in the game is resolved using a variant of the Icon System that is featured in Last Unicorn's Star Trek: The Next Generation RPG.
categories: Movies / TV / Radio theme, Science Fiction
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Point to Point Movement

name: Elmo's Lunch Bunch
description: Elmo wants to know, "What's for lunch?" Help Elmo and his Sesame Street friends match up secret lunch box surprises! Secret food cards are hidden inside 16 plastic lunch boxes on the gameboard. Most of the cards picture a favorite lunchtime food, but some cards picture Oscar's icky garbage. (Yuck!) To win, be the first player to find the two secret food cards that match your two game cards!
categories: Children's Game, Memory, Movies / TV / Radio theme

name: Den letzten beissen die Hunde
description:
in a round course with plates of different colors the player throw the dice and move their pawns clockwise. At a certain plate the dog is waiting. The player whose pawn is most far away from the dog's mouth gets a bone from the nearest player.
when one player has no more bones, the player with the most bones wins.

name: Sambesi
description: The infamous animal catcher Sandro Saebel has caught wild animals and cooped them up in an enclosure. The players have the task to set the animals free before Sandro is aware of it. For each animal that is brought back the player gets points. Motor is a die, which let small wooden boats through the river.
mechanics: Area Movement, Dice Rolling, Hand Management

name: Piks!
description:
Content: 37 cards in three colors with number 1-10,
10 is double, 4 watering cans

At the beginning each player gets a watering can for his hand.
8 cards are put face down in the middle of the table.
The rest of the cards are put face up and mixed up at the table. The players take turns in taking one open or one blind card, until all cards are dealt equally.
All players lay out a blind card. At the same time they are opened. Are there any with the same color?
If this happens, that player with the highest value of this color gets all cards.
After all cards are played each of the players count their
cards. The winner has the fewest cards.

name: Earth Vs. the Flying Saucers
description:
From the web site...

General Stormgunden chewed on his cigar and grumbled under his breath. “Damn aliens have destroyed Chicago Mr. President,” He offered as he watched the president pale at the thought of the aliens making their way to D.C. Ever since the Hamster incident, the President had suffered bouts of doubt and indecision. Sure the nukes used on the monster Hamster had laid waste to half the country, but hell, that still left the other half radiation free. In his option, the general thought, that was a good trade off.

Now though, the strange aliens had arrived, destroying ever city that lay in their path. Their flying saucers were damn near unbeatable.

“We got only one choice sir.” the General offered, “Nukes!”

This is the newest Mini-Game from Bad Baby Productions. The world has survived the rampage of the giant Hamster, Mr. Chips, but can it survive the invasion of aliens, aliens armed with flying saucers and death rays. Only you can stop them, that or watch the world burn. The sequel to Bad Baby’s popular Hamster that Ate the World Mini-Game, Earth Vs. the Flying Saucers takes that great game system and stands it on its head. Have fun trying to take over the world or try to defend it with the frail, weakling human forces.

name: Shrek 3: The Castle
description:
From the box:

Be the first to arrive at the Castle and claim victory! The road to the castle is full of pitfalls... Beware of some of the characters you may meet along the way. Luckily Shrek and his friends are there to lend a hand. Sometimes Merlin's magic will help you, sometimes not... But never forget that the aim of the game is to HAVE FUN!

Enjoy the Game.
___

The game is basically a "move along the path" derivative with the addition of "Merlin's magic cards" which can have characters move forward or back along the board. First one to 100 (by exact roll) wins the game.

name: Great Moves
description: Try to draw the object on the card and have your team mates guess what it is. Drawings are made with a marker attached to a random part of the body (determined by a spinner) and made on a slate attached to a team mate's body at another random body location (bottom included). An odd variant of pictionary.

name: Familie Brumm
description: Memory game. Players move any bear around the wheel attempting to find the matching sized knife, fork or plate. If it doesn't match, you don't get it, and the next player goes. First player to 3 identical sized pieces or any six tiles wins.

name: Fischzug
description:
Every day courageous sailors go on a dangerous trip to the fishing areas of the world. They throw out their nets and hope of the biggest catch of their lives.
In this game the winner is the player who gets the most points out of his catch before an arranged number of fishing trips are completed.

name: Feuerdrache
description:
2 to 4 small dragons always run to a volcano in order to get fresh fire stones for their store cupboard.
On the way there are surprising trade transactions. Which dragon has the most fire stones at the end?

name: Zaubertrank
description: Each player plays the role of a magician who has to brew a magic potion. They need ingredients for it. The magicians walk through the forest to search for those ingredients. In some fields they find only one half of a ingredient and have to look for the other half. The winner is the player who accumulates all of the needed ingredients first.

name: Oh, wie schön ist Panama
description: We travel with Tiger and Bear through Panama, the land of their dreams. You smell bananas there, wherever you are. On their trip they meet a lot of friendly animals, go by raft and have to go across bridges in order to finally come back home happy . In order that no one dies of hunger everyone gets a cooking pot, anyone else goes fishing at the neighbor... Whoever returns back home first wins.

name: Clothespins! Game
description:
Briarpatch website description:

Hang onto your shorts! Clothespins! Is the fast paced,strategy game where players score points by completing clotheslines of matching patterns or items of laundry. But watch out for the birds they may fly off with your boxers!

name: Märchenland
description:
This is a children's game based on the fairy-tales by the Brothers Grimm.

It comes with a colorful board, 36 story tiles, 4 player pawns and a six-sided die. The rulebook also contains the nine stories found in the game.

Players roll to move their pawns along the track, collecting sets of tiles.

From the box cover:

Märchenland - "Das Spiel mit 9 berühmten Märchen de Gebrüder Grimm"

And on the back of the box:

Die Spieledee
"Es war einmal ein Zauberwald. Dort machten sich lustige kleine Zwerge auf den Weg nach 9 Märchen der Gebrüder Grimm zu suchen. Seit vielen Jahren hält in dem Zauberwald eine Fee die Märchen in ihrem Bann.
Nun gilt es, diese 9 Märchen zu befreien. Manchmal auch mit Unterstützung des Zauberstables. Auf geht's ihr flinken Zwerge und huscht durch Zauberwald!"
mechanics: Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Storytelling, Tile Placement

name: Barbie Butterfly Princess
