description:
"... enter this enchanted garden and become Butterfly Princess Barbie! Spin the magic wand spinner and watch the butterflies flutter. Move your Butterfly Princess along the path and collect three butterflies first to win the game!"

Includes colorful board, spinner assembly, four stand-up Barbie figures, rings, and rules.

Players should be Ages 5 and up.

(c)1995 Mattel Item #7200
mechanics: Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection

name: Im Bärenwald
description: In a forest clearing the small bears have built a playground. They have created 3 games they play there: "Hi-Hei-Ho", "Bären-Wettlauf" and "Bäumchen pflanzen".
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Memory, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Mad Lab
description:
From the box:

Four mad professors locked in a lab cooking up potions, conjuring a trap!

Inside the flask bouncing around, lurks their creation trying to get out.

Everyone's wary, passing the flask. No one is sure when the cork will go pop!

MAD LAB is the manic game where you don't want to be GLOOPED by a LITTLE GREEN MONSTER!

Keep the flask moving, ducking this way and that - any time now it's going to go BLAT!

Three strikes and you're out. Last one alive makes it out of the Mad Lab!
categories: Action / Dexterity, Children's Game, Electronic, Real-time

name: Monopoly: Shrek Collector's
description:
This 2007 collector's edition of Monopoly features locations from the popular Shrek animated film trilogy in place of the traditional Atlantic City streets. Instead of advancing to Boardwalk or taking a ride on the Reading, you will now visit Shrek's Swamp or hitch a ride in an Onion Carriage. In addition, the locations are grouped so that like locations are in the same color-group. For example, the orange group (traditionally St. James Place, Tennessee Avenue, and New York Avenue) are now Charming's Dinner Theater, The Poison Apple, and Tower Castle-which in the films were presented as places where villains were found. Special tokens are included for this version-Pinocchio, Gingy, Puss in Boots, Donkey, Fiona, and Shrek. Chance and Community Chest are replaced with Spells and Potions, and Houses and Hotels are recolored teal and purple, and are called Cottages and Castles. Also includes special bank notes which feature the heroes on the face. The bills are as follows:

1's-Pinocchio
5's-The Three Little Pigs & Big Bad Wolf
10's-Gingy
20's-Puss in Boots
50's-Donkey
100's-Fiona
500's-Shrek
categories: Economic, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Negotiation
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Player Elimination, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Trading

name: Kontact
description:
Using their wooden playing pieces (40 each), players race to complete 10 buildings before their opponent. Pieces are placed on the board in contact with a piece of the opposing colour. When enough pieces are in play, those on the board can be stacked atop opposing pieces, or other pieces may be brought into play. A player may complete a building building if the topmost piece is his.

Can be played in teams of 2 or 3 each with an additional set.

name: Long Live Rock
description:
From the publisher:

Race against time to unscramble Rock and Roll's greatest moments! Long Live Rock is the un-trivia game that challenges you to put all of the famous people, places, music, and events on the time line of Rock and Roll. Every second counts as you arrange significant Rock happenings in chronological order. Guess the correct year of a Rock happening and go on to win. A great party game for music lovers.

For 1 or more players or teams. Ages 14 and up
publishers: Aleken Games, Vintage Sports Cards, Inc.

name: Strike
description:
Strike! is a loosely based simulation of the British car industry of the 1970's and was published free in a 1981 edition of Games & Puzzles magazine.

Players are paired together and act as representatives of their respective car manufactures. Each of the pair takes on the role of managing director, the other as union leader of its' work force.

The role of the managing director is one of expanding sales and profits against competition from other managing directors in the rival car firms.

The role of the union leader is to secure fair deal for the workers and secure the highest possible share of the company profits against the resistance of the management.

Strike! asks you to do the impossible: combine with players holding diametrically opposite interests to achieve your objectives within the company while helping to sweep the competition from the market.

name: Bunjee
description: Bunjee is a simple dice rolling game with some risk management. Each player is playing a figure jumping from a tree, trying to fall low enough to reach the goal but not too low to avoid crashing on the floor. On his turn, the player launch the dies, hecks the result and decides to satisfy himself with the result of the dices or roll some dices again to better his score. Of course, re-rolling the dices includes some risk. Mechanism is very close to the Can't Stop from Sid Sackson.

name: Hazar
description:
The aim of the game is to win all 60 chips. Before playing starts the chips are given a certain value. It is allow just to play for the own honor.

From the designer:

In fact, Hazar is some kind of "Las Vegas in your pocket", played in Bars and Cafes, by groups having fun with losing or winning money... There are 60 steel-chips. Up to 12 players (5 chips each) put their chips on numbers in different combinations. The stakes are high, because, in the end, there is only one player, who wins the 60 chips.

name: The Table Cricket Game
description:
The Table Cricket Game is played (as noted in the rules) "...as per the rules of real one-day limited over cricket." The batsman draws cards from a deck and the fielder places his pawns on the spaces on the board marked by dots, such as "silly point" and "midoff." The batsman then plays his cards one after the other, and tallies his runs. Each card has a type of hit (such as "Full-blooded drive to Mid-on") as well as a F and NF section, showing how many runs would be scored if the fielder has placed a pawn there (F for "fielder") or if there is no fielding pawn there (NF for "no fielder"). Scores are tabulated on the score sheet pads.

No publisher or designer was listed on the box.

name: Das Geheimnis der Erfolgreichen
description:
Triva game with a 'Success'-theme. Players need several abilities - e.g. luck, knowledge, teamplay - to win this game.

Be the first obtaining a (coloured) card of each area (totally 5);
roll the die and move your token (you may roll again once, if you are not pleased with the result);
depending on the space you landed on you must perform an action:
1. Green: Active player draws a card and reading the green question - all other players make short notices/remarks about it (hidden);
active player has to assign answers to players - successful? If yes get a green pyramid.
2. Grey: Use your sawy! Find correct answer to a question within a minute - you may ask for assistance (one person only).
Example: Find the correspondent city in Europe with the letters R_I_M_D_D_A; successful (correct answers on the back of the card)? You and your partner will collect a grey pyramid.
3. Blue: find within 30 s (with or without a partner) correct answer; example: How many wings does a dragonfly have?
4. Red: Describe within 60 s together with a player of your choice - word after word - searched term, e.g. opera; successful... get a red pyramid.
5. Golden: All players form their own 'five-digit' number. Push your luck - shuffle 10 numbered cards (0 - 9), draw 5 out of them and turn them over step by step. After each step players have to make up their decisions placing this digit. Highest number wins a golden pyramid.
6. Coloured: your choice
7. White: steal a pyramid of your choice from another player
8. Ending a full circuit: get a pyramid of your choice
TRADING RATE: 2 pyramids (same colour) = 1 card (same colour)
mechanics: Acting, Cooperative Game, Dice Rolling, Open Drafting, Push Your Luck, Set Collection, Storytelling, Team-Based Game

name: Solar Conflict
description: Conquer the other players Home-Planet with one of your Spaceships.

name: I See Three
description:
BELOIT, Wis. – In Patch Products’ new I See Three!™ preschool game, players put on Magic Reveal Glasses to see the hidden animals, reptiles, fish and bugs on the game chips.

The red pair of glasses reveals some creatures, but they disappear when you switch to the blue or green glasses. You’ll have to remember where they are so you can shout “I See Three!” when you match three of the same kind. Collect the most sets of three, and you win!

Players take turns discarding cards to represent the throw of a bowling ball with up to two throws per frame - the goal is to get all 10 pins in each frame either with a "strike" (get all 10 pins at once by playing one card) or by finishing off the unclaimed pins on the second card with a "spare".

Each game consists of 10 frames, and the game is scored via regulation American bowling rules. A "Captain" player keeps score on a laminated scoresheet for all players. With 2+ players, the player with the highest score at the end of 10 frames wins. With solo play, you try to beat your previous best score. The highest possible score is 300 points!

The original (1960) edition contained two decks of cards (108 total), enough for 1 to 4 players to play right out of the box. The 1964 edition came with only one deck of 54 cards supporting either one or two players unless you purchased a second set of 54 cards separately to allow play with up to 4 people (the laminated scorecard in both versions includes 4 player lines to support up to four players).

Trivia: The yellow 1964 "Authorized Edition" box shows the game named "Don Carter's Strike! Bowling Game" and doesn't mention "300" anywhere on the box, but the instructions only refer to the game as "300" and don't mention Don Carter anywhere! The most likely reason is that they licensed Don's endorsement for the 1964 edition of the game but neglected to update the rules sheet to accommodate the newer name. Don was and is (apparently) widely considered the greatest bowler of all time.

name: La Mayor Hazaña de la Historia
description:
This game depicts the events regarding the Discovery of America. It consists of two phases, the first one on land and the second one in the ocean. In the first phase, players must travel to Portugal, visit Duke of Medinaceli and the Prior of the Monastery in La Rábida, among others, in order to get Recommendation Cards to be able to get an audience with the Catholic Monarchs (Reyes Católicos). Once they get support from the Kings, players will buy food provisions, ships, hire the crew and set sail into the unknown...
In the second phase, players will have to sail across the immense ocean in order to discover the New World and be able to bring back the news to Spain.

This game (chosen as the Official Game of the 5th Centennial of the Discovery of America) offers you the possibility to become a Hero (the title translates to "the greatest feat/heroic deed, in history").

The contents of the game are the following:
- Semi-reversible game board
- 70 game cards (Event, 'Self Confidence', 'Recommendation Card', Royal Permission and Pinzón Brothers)
- 6 Columbus pawns
- 42 crew counters (21 and 21 sailors)
- 40 food counters
- 84 Ducat Coins (28 of each 1500, 500 and 100)
- 6 Caravels
- 2 Dice
- Rulebook

name: Sherlock Holmes
description: The play of the game is simple and very exciting, and is entirely new. Any number, from 3-8 can take part. The object is to capture as many "burglers", "robbers" and "thieves" cards as possible and to obtain the valuable "Sherlock Holmes" cards. All players play at once and there is never a dull moment. A large part of the fun of the game consists in making a "sweep" by turning up the card "Sherlock Holmes" thus allowing you to quickly seize an opponents pile of cards which would contain the most "robbers", "thieves" and "burglers". Players can also call "Scotland Yard", forcing everyone to pass 3 cards to the player on his left. The first player to 50 points wins the game.
categories: Action / Dexterity, Card Game, Novel-based, Real-time
mechanics: Hand Management, Open Drafting, Pattern Recognition, Set Collection, Speed Matching

name: Stix
description:
Stix is a set of:
50 wood rods
4 figures
1 target
1 Game rules with three Games

PICASSO
Think of a word or a term and then lay it with the wood rods

Al CAPONE
The board is made with the wood rods and you have to collect the most of them.

FLIPPER
A dexterity game where you have to hit the target.
categories: Abstract Strategy, Action / Dexterity, Party Game
mechanics: Roll / Spin and Move, Tile Placement

name: Love is Letting Go of Fear Game
description:
"A non-competitive sharing experience" based on the best selling book by Dr. Gerald G. Jampolsky.

In the mold of The Ungame, this non-competitive experience was designed to create a TIME and PLACE for people to talk openly and honestly about their feelings, ideas, personal experiences, and needs as they learn the principles of LOVE. Participants respond to a variety of activities found on the cards and gameboard following de rigeur roll of the dice.

"This Game Can Change Your Life!"

name: McWiz Junior Deluxe
description:
McWiz Junior Deluxe contains all new questions in three age categories: 6-7, 8-9, and 10-12, all specifically geared to reinforce education -- many questions are taken from actual scholastic texts. As each card has a question from each age category, the game allows children of different age groups to play together.

Each correct answer earns the player (or team) a piece of a jigsaw puzzle; the first to complete their puzzle is the winner.

This deluxe edition comes packaged in a premium, house-shaped container.

name: Question of Hockey 2
description:
A Question of Hockey II is, appropriately enough, a hockey trivia game. It is the follow up to A Question of Hockey, and consists of 1200 all new questions in the following four categories:


Numbers & Nicknames
Original six
Trophies & Records
Hodgepodge.


Gameplay takes place over three "periods", with the possibility of "overtime" in case of a tie, much like in a real game of hockey.

The rules can be viewed for free at the following URL:

http://www.mcwiz.com/documents/rules_mcwiz/qh2_rulesenglish....

name: Near vs Normal Chess
description:
Near vs Normal Chess pits pieces following Near Chess rules against those following normal chess rules. Either black or white side can play with the Near Chess rules, while the other side plays with regular chess rules. Players need to decide at the start of the game which pawn promotion and win conditions are used (Near or normal chess rules).

People are encouraged to either download the rules here or read the rules on the Chess Variants website:
http://www.chessvariants.org/index/msdisplay.php?itemid=MSne...

name: Monopoly: Karlsruhe
description:
A monopoly (from Greek monos μόνος (alone or single) + polein πωλεῖν (to sell)) exists when a specific person or enterprise is the only supplier of a particular commodity.

Monopoly is a roll-and-move game where players move around the game board buying or trading properties, developing their properties with houses and hotels. When opponents land on players owned property, the owning player collects rent from the landing player. Owning sets of properties increases the rent paid to the player who owns them, by the player who lands on the square. The ultimate goal is to have the most money and drive opponents into bankruptcy.

The classic Monopoly with constructions and other elements of Karlsruhe, in Germany.
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Player Elimination, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Trading

name: Back to Blighty
description:
Back to Blighty is a diceless card game, which is played mainly with 4 decks of terrain cards and a player sheet.

Your plane is shot down over enemy occupied France and you manage to find a French family but you cannot stay there too long you must find the safe house.

6 different pilots with different characteristics to choose from 12 different routes that must be followed. You have 4 different terrain types, Countryside, road, river and railway. Traveling by night you pick a relevant card which has a distance and time these are moved along a track. The longer you are out the more tired you become, but you must find somewhere to rest before daylight comes. some cards are German soldiers but these may be avoided if the conditions are right, if you are challenged I hope your language skills are up to scratch and that the 6 days in the outdoors isn't going to give you away.

Tactical decisions include how long into the morning are you prepared to travel before you find somewhere to rest for the day, balance this with how good will you be if you were challenged by a German soldier. How far you have to travel before your safe compared to the fact the more days your out the more disheveled you look and therefor more suspicious.

Other things included are crossing rivers, swimming, boat, or bridge, weather which may change half way through the night. The heavier the rain the less likely you will be challenged but the less rest you will get. Going into a town to seek resistance members but beware the Gestapo and German sympathizers. Stamina, food, blending in, stealing a German soldiers push-bike all take a role.
categories: Card Game, Print & Play, World War II

name: Ancient Wargames Rules
description:
A set of Ancient Wargame Rules designed for use with 15mm or 25mm figures.

Infantry, cavalry and camels are on a ratio of 1 figure per 20 actual troops.

Elephants, chariots, transport and artillery pieces are on a scale on 1 model per 8 actual pieces.

The set of rules is closely aligned with the set released by Wargames Research Group (WRG). Action is based on an Igo/Ugo system, without the need for written orders.

name: Arena
description:
“A Game of Fantasy Gladiatorial Combat for 2-6 players. The players take the roles of owners of a team of warriors who do battle in The Arena, a circle of battle, blood and death. Their teams consist of brave Humans, the graceful, catlike Ptemet, the insectoid Keet’Norn, the brutish Orghar, and the deadly Vashail, who battle for glory, money and at their master’s whim. Life is cheap, death is easy, but glory is eternal!”

The players are allocated funds to set up their gladiatorial team. Warriors, weapons and armor must be purchased. In addition, there are campaign rules to chart a team’s progress from one game to the next.

name: Golden Axe
description:
“Solitaire Card game. Based on the side-scroller video game of the same name.”

The player starts with five characters, a Warrior, Dwarf, Woman Warrior, Sprite, and Centaur. Each character is rated for Hits, Magic, Speed, Damage Bonus, and Weapon.

The card deck contains six types of cards: Attack, Defend, Heal, Speed, Magic, and Foe. The player must defeat a series of Foes to reach and confront the Death Adder. The player wins the game by defeating the Death Adder.

name: Baroque Masters
description:
“Each player is an Architect in Rome during the Baroque Era 1600's. Players try to increase their own reputation at the expense of their Rivals. Victory: When the deck runs out a second time, the player with the most Reputation Points (RP) wins.”

The game is played with a custom deck of cards which come in five types: Patrons, Commissions, Quality, Actions, and Events. The players score points by playing melds consisting of a Patron Card and a Commission Card. In addition, any number of Quality cards may be added to the meld to increase the number of Reputation Points received for the meld.

name: BESM
description:
An anime themed card game. The name stands for “Big Eyes, Small Mouth”, a description reflecting the appearance of anime characters. The players compete to be the first to capture 200+ Force Points worth of Foes. Foes are captured by forming teams of Friend cards to battle and capture the Foes.

The game is played with two decks - the Foes Deck and the Friends deck.

The Foes Deck contains a total of 31 Foes (Devils, Ghosts, Ninjas, etc.) and Minions (such as Cat Girls, Lesser Demons, and the Inept Recurring Nemesis.)

The Friends Deck contains over 120 cards in 16 different types: Event, Character, Companion, Fight, Vehicle, Mech, Magic, Power, Tech, Attribute, Shape, Enhancer, Flaw, Gun, Sword, and Location.
categories: Card Game, Comic Book / Strip, Movies / TV / Radio theme

name: Chinese Rummy
description:
“Chinese symbolism theme with rummy/poker mechanics. The Deck: Players share a common deck. The deck contains 27 cards. There are 5 Suites each with 5 cards numbered 1-5.”

The five suits are Elements, Blessings, Virtues, Directions, and Beasts for Sacrifice. In addition there is one Ying and one Yang card. The first player to play a five card meld wins the games.

There are three types of melds: flush, straight (all from different suits), and five of a kind. The Yin card serves as a wild card for a flush, the Yang cards serves as a wild card for a five of a kind.

name: Fall of France
description:
“Solo Card Game. 10 May 1940. The player takes the role of the Germans invading the Western Democracies. There are two decks: The Allied Deck and the German Deck.”

To advance your campaign, you must play melds with a higher Force total than the Allied Cards on the table.

“Objective: You win if you run the Allied deck out of cards. The Allied forces collapse and you conquer France in 6 weeks. If you ever accumulate 7 delay tokens, the Allies have stopped you and you must fight a long war against France.”
categories: Card Game, Print & Play, World War II

name: Farmers
description:
A card game of competitive farming.

Resource Cards represent crops and animals on the farm. Points are scored by having Resource Cards in play when a matching Market Card is played by any player. In addition, there are Setback Cards which cause all players with certain Resource Cards in play to lose points. The game ends when one or more players reach twenty or more points.
categories: Card Game, Economic, Farming, Print & Play

name: Fiefs
description:
“Medieval Dukes contest for gold and lands. Object: The player with the most gold at the end of the game wins. Board: The board is a 3x3 grid. The Central square is the Palace. The 8 Surrounding squares are the lesser Fiefs. Deck: Players use a common deck. The deck contains 78 cards.”

Each player starts with one corner Fief, six Gold, three Bishops, four Nobles, five Knights, and a hand of seven cards from a custom card deck. The players obtain gold by controlling squares on the board – one gold for each Fief and two gold for the Palace.
categories: Card Game, Fighting, Medieval, Print & Play

name: Marvel Ultimate Battles
description: Aimed at a younger audience Marvel Ultimate Battles is a new easy-to-learn TCG featuring characters from the Marvel line of comics. Play as Captain America, Spider-Man, Wolverine and more in a fast-paced battle to to see who will be the last one left standing!

name: Loto points rouges
description:
Each player tries to fill dots on special cards common to all players by playing dotted pattern tiles from his hand. A player that succeeds in completing one special (contract) card collects as many tokens as that the card has dots and a new special card is drawn from the reserve to continue play.

The player who collects the most tokens at the end of the game wins.

name: Arena: Horácios e Curiácios
description:
A simulation of the battle between the Horatii and the Curiatii brothers during the war between Rome and Alba Longa (7th century BC).
Contains some element of roleplaying, as each combatant is individually created, detailed and activated.

name: Range War
description:
"Wargame of the American West circa 1840-1900. Players are rival Land Barons trying to gain complete control of the same territory. Victory: Control all Settlements on the Board. Players are eliminated if their Baron is killed."

The game is played on a hex map showing thirty settlements. Each player chooses to play one of four ranches and the ranches are placed on settlements that are far apart. The remaining settlement spaces have a random settlement counter placed on them. The settlements are thereby determined to be farms, mines, towns, or trading posts.

Each player starts with a Baron counter and two Regulator counters. The players gain revenue from their ranches and from other settlements they control. Revenue is used to recruit new units and to provide upkeep for the units a player controls.
categories: American West, Economic, Fighting, Print & Play

name: Africa
description:
A solo card game of exploration and conquest in Africa. Playable solo, or with two or three players.

The game is played with three custom card decks, the Province Deck, Unit Deck and Event Deck. There Province Deck has cards for eight provinces, each rated for income and defense. The Event Deck contains favorable and cataclysmic events.

The Unit Deck has Native, Colonial, European, and Rebel Armies. The Rebel Armies represent the forces the player must eliminate from the provinces. The player must pay upkeep for all friendly armies in the provinces.

The player may also build settlements, towns, and forts in a province. These installations alter the income or defense values of a province.

name: Pocket Geni Rock & Pop
description: A trivia game where you roll you're category by rolling a special die. If you're answer is correct you note it on a grid. If you got four answers on a row on the grid you win.

name: Flip Four
description:
Flip Four is a set of four games, all of which are played with 49 of the cards from a standard deck, placed in a 7x7 grid. They also share the central mechanism, which is turning over a card which is in the same row or column as a card of the same suit or rank.


In Matchline a token moves to a matching card and then the previous card is flipped. The goal is to flip as many cards as possible. If more than one person plays they each need their own deck and compete to get the best score for the same layout.



Connections is the same as Matchline except that any card with a match may be flipped; there is no token.



Saboteur is for three players, who are dealt three specific removed cards. One card designates the saboteur, who scores for cards not flipper, while the other two players score for flipped cards. If two players vote that the third is the saboteur the accused player must stop playing.



Cross/Block is for two players: one tries to connect two opposite edges with a chain of flipped cards and the other tries to prevent this.

name: ESCAPE!
description:
This game is played on chess sized board. Up to 4 players will maneuver around, trying to collect 6 keys E , S , C , A , P , E! to Escape! They will have to dodge the guards or else will get sent back to their cell. On your turn you have 4 moves, in which you can move the guards, the keys and yourself.

Get this game here: http://www.printgames.net/english/detail_e/escape.htm

name: DinoX
description: Based on the hit show from the BBC "Walking with Dinosaurs", this trivia game features cards with 1500 questions, 4 realistic dinosaur skeletons to assemble, and a DVD with footage from the show. Every question you answer correctly, you get to put another piece on your dinosaur skeleton. Race to be the first to complete your skeleton.
categories: Animals, Educational, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Trivia
publishers: BD2 Games, Educa Borras, Pressman Toy Corp., TV-Fun

name: Shakeout
description:
Denys Fisher had a reputation for producing some very 'different' games - not least Shakeout which involves each player taking hold of a plastic sphere filled with plastic sticks, and having to shake it frantically to 'spill' out the contents. These are then subsequently placed in various combinations upon a plastic scoreboard in a race to create the maximum points. The first Player to empty his 'sphere' and score the most is the winner!

An unusual game, and one that is so simple it is consequently overlooked.

c1971

name: Bombs Away
description:
Bombs Away is a carrier game. You have carriers, battleships, cruisers, frigates, subs, bombers and fighters all to do battle against your opponent across an ocean map.
This was the designer's first game.

name: Cattle Drive
description: This is a card game about a cattle drive where you want to be the first player to get 1000 cattle to market per hand and 5000 per game. You have cards such as droughts, fires, water holes, wagons and more to prevent you opponent from getting his cattle to market, and to get more cattle of yours sold.
categories: American West, Card Game, Print & Play

name: Fire Away
description:
Just a plain infantry war game with a few ships and airplanes....very simple. Using simple counters and a one page map, this game lets you play a quick game without many complicated rules.

Full Game: http://www.cruzan.info/pgames/pgames.html

name: Paper Football League
description:
This is part card game and part board game for football (American). Some real simple plays both offensive and defensive. A sample league provided. There are different cards included, both offensive and defensive cards. You play your cards to try to get the football to score.

Full Game Here: http://www.cruzan.info/pgames/pgames.html

name: Sour Grapes
description:
Aim of the game:
To collect enough grapes (green tokens) to cover the card.

Each player has a card depicting grapes.
on each card there are 5 "sour grape" bad circles, only known to the owner.
Each player is given 12 tokens (grapes) to cover the 5 bad circles and 7 additional circles.

Player A takes one token from the player on his right and continue taken tokens from the other players until he takes a token which was placed in a bad "sour grape" circle. At this point the next player does the same operation, collecting tokens until s/he graps one that was a sour grape.
The winner is the player who completes his/her card first.

name: Bible Tik Tak Toe
description:
Bible Tik Tak Toe

"Answer Bible questions, learn Bible facts, and enjoy Tik Tak Toe fun!"

Designed for 2 players or 2 teams, this religion game features 6 large illustrated tic-tac-toe boards and 12 easy to handle tiles. Includes a 64 page question/answer booklet.

Ages 8 - 12

(c)1994 Standard Publishing

28-02654

name: Traps & Treasures
description:
Components:
-16 playing cards. Use all of the face cards and aces from a standard deck of poker cards.
-two uniquely colored pawns, one for each player.
-4x4 playing board

Win by guessing the location of your opponent’s treasure before they find yours.

Set a Trap & Hide your Treasure.
On a player’s turn they must move their pawn and they may optionally make one guess as to where their opponent’s treasure is hidden. To move a player plays one card and moves their pawn to a space in the row (or column) which is labeled with that card.

http://www.superpowernosissies.com/games/
categories: Bluffing, Card Game, Print & Play, Spies/Secret Agents

name: IQ Master
description:
The players place their tokens on the start space.Each turn the players throw a die. If a 1 is thrown the player can move the pawn to the next field. When a player throws 2 - 5 the player takes a card from the pile. The player reads the question on the card aloud. The hourglass is turned and every player, including the player who had read the card, has 2 minutes to give the right answer. If a player knows the answer, he/she shouts 'stop.' When it is the correct answer that player may move its pawn to the next grey circle corresponding to the number on the card. Otherwise the player has to move backwards to the circle with the same number. If a 6 is thrown the player may choose a card from the pile.
When there is no time left and nobody has given the correct answer, then the next player starts its turn. The first player who reaches the last space, wins the game.

A variant of the game is to write down the answer and compare them when the time is up. All the players move their tokens forward or backwards.
mechanics: Open Drafting, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Kreativ Quiz
description:
An unusual trivia Game, Kreativ Quiz combines 8 different questioning games into one. The themes you get asked about are:
Loose words
Knowledge of human nature
Nature and environment
Celebrities
Guess the profession
Knowing the world
Scribbling Stuff
Conundrums

name: Sprinter 3D
description:
French cycling game covering the Paris Roubaix race, the Alpe D'Huez climb and an indoor race. Contains 12 riders (2 per team), 4 A3 panels and a rule set.

Players secretly distribute a given number of energy points between the riders of their team. This distribution remains secret during all the race. In every rider's turn, he choses to throw one, two or three dice (remember, the dice are 122223) and crosses the same number of energy points. All the riders in a group can follow the leader of the group at no cost. Furthermore, the leader of the peloton advancess less than te thow of the dice (depending on the type of terrain). Every rider must advance at least once, can chose the dide of the road. Since the right side of the road plays frst, the rider in front of the pack will try to move to the left side of the road.
mechanics: Roll / Spin and Move, Secret Unit Deployment, Simulation

name: Pass The Pyramids
description:
A "Dicehouse" game for 3 to 5 players.

Players win or lose tokens on the toss of their pyramids, scoring points based on how they land. The winner is the player with the most tokens when one player busts.

Rules can be found at the Icehouse Games Wiki

Game System

Icehouse Pieces

name: Atome crochu
description:
Contents: a board with a central 7×7 playing area and two areas for arranging pawns, 12 white marbles and 12 black marbles, 3 sheepfold pawns and 3 nuclear pawns , 3 special dices with the symbols “sun”, “radiation” and blank faces.

The “sun” player handles the sheepfold pawns and the white marbles, while the “radiation” player deals with the nuclear pawns and the black marbles. According to the roll of the dices, players set marbles on the board which allows to build or destroy sheepfold and nuclear power stations, and to capture or to free pawns. The first to build three nuclear power stations or three sheepfolds wins the game.

name: Campaign
description: Campaign (also known as "Buck 20") is a simplified version of Chess, designed to be a good introductory game, easier to teach and to learn. The board size is reduced to 5x7. There are no knights or queens, nor are there "en passant" captures. The medieval piece names have been replaced with modern political terms: candidate, bodyguard, handler, and intern. Coins are used for playing pieces: one player plays heads and the other plays tails. For a more tense game, play for keeps.

name: Flinke Bürste
description:
The title translates to Quick (tooth) Brush.

Two horseshoe shaped wood pieces carry 20 wooden teeth pieces, zero to three wood rings are laid over the teeth, the players walk around this "mouth" with their pieces, wooden tooth brushes. One die shows how far they may go, another die specifies what action to perform: brush away one ring, two rings, do nothing or advance a bacterium to the teeth.
If the bacterium reaches the teeth before the players have cleaned all of them, the players lose.

name: Archean Empires
description:
"Area Control game for 2-6 players. Early Earth Primitive Microbial Life Forms Compete for Territory." Each player represents one of six different Microbial Kingdoms which have special attributes or abilities.

The game is played on a map composed of 64 Territories. Each space on the board has a set resource value from 0 to 5. The resource value governs the maximum number of Biomass Tokens that may occupy the Territory at the end of each turn.

"The Game ends when all territories are filled up to their
Max population levels." Victory Points are then awarded based on factors such as the number of Territories a player controls and the number of Biomass Tokens each player has in play. The player with the most Victory Points wins the game.

name: Warp Empires
description:
"Generic rule set for a series of empire building/conquest games."

Games designed to be played using the Warp Empires system are called Warp Empires modules. Each module describes the units and other components needed to play the module.

Warp Empires modules are generally played on a map composed of irregular areas or territories. Counters are used to represent units, items, and control markers.

Card play is central to the system. One or more Action Decks are used in each module. Action Cards are played to move units or stacks. In addition, some Action Cards provide benefits in combat.

Victory conditions generally involve controlling a certain number of territories or destroying all opposing forces, as specified in the individual Warp Empires module.

The following games use the Warp Empires system:


Babylon 5 Empires
Conquest of Demara
Dark Sun Empires
Doctor Who Empires
Doom Trooper Empires



Empires of Mystara
Europe at War
Federation
Land War in Asia
Lord of the Abyss



Middle Earth Empires
Scortch
Space 1889 Empires
Star Wars Campaign
Union & Confederacy



Warcraft Empires
War Hammer Space Empires
War of Independence
Warp Hammer Empires

name: Filmfestival
description:
A Swedish quiz game about film. Contains 816 questions in the following categories:

- Hollywood
- Actors/Actresses
- Europe
- Horror & Comedy
- Sweden
- Misc

Each player starts with a ticket for each category. When you correctly answer a question at one of the cinemas the corresponding ticket is used. When you have used all of your tickets you can start the walk up the stairs to Kinski Bar. The winner is the player who first reaches Kinski Bar.
categories: Movies / TV / Radio theme, Party Game, Trivia
publishers: Eastman Kodak Company, Göteborg Film Festival, Ohlsson & Lohaven

name: Egg Chess
description:
A game like Tic-Tac-Toe, but instead of using circles and crosses uses eggs in different forms. On a 3×3 board, players take turns either adding an egg to an empty square, or changing an egg. The egg can be a whole egg, broken egg, or empty egg.

A whole egg can turn into a broken egg or an empty egg,
A broken egg can turn into an empty egg,
And an empty egg cannot be reformed.


The player who gets three of the same form of eggs in a line on the 3×3 grid wins.

name: Star Fleets
description:
"Card game for two players. Battle between opposing fleets in the Star Trek Universe."

"The Decks: Each player gets one unique deck."

The game includes decks for the United Federation of Planets, the Klingon Empire, the Romulan Star Empire, the Kzinti Hegemony, the Gorn Confederation, the Tholian Holdfast, the Hydran Kingdom, and the Lyran Star Empire.

"Cards: Types of cards include: Ships, Personnel, Control, and Combat cards."

"Each player starts with a Fleet Total of 100 points. You win if you reduce your opponents Fleet Total to zero points."
categories: Fighting, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Science Fiction

name: Tavern Brawl
description:
"Card Game for 2 (or more) players. Common Deck CCG Format. Fantasy Theme. A Fight breaks out at Ye Olde Dragon Tavern (& Inn). Recruit Characters to 'your side' to knock out your opponent’s Characters and drink all his beer."

"Characters have 2 Stats: Hits & Strength. Each Character has one or more traits, such as Mage or Fighter."

"Each player starts with 10 Bottles of Beer on the Wall."

"Victory: Reduce your opponent to zero Beers."

name: Napoleonic Empire
description:
"Two player strategic war game set in the Napoleonic era. One player controls France & Napoleon. The other player controls the Allies. The allies include England, Russia, Prussia, and Austria."

This area movement game uses generic units. Cards provide for combat bonuses and other effects, such as additional reinforcements.
"Victory: The Allies win if they control France at the end of their turn. The French win if they control all continental countries at the end of their turn."
categories: Card Game, Fighting, Napoleonic, Print & Play

name: Viking Loot
description:
"Players control Viking clans that raid settlements on the Mainland. The player with the most loot at the end of 20 turns is the winner."

In this simple game of exploration and conquest, the players may build, recruit or buy six types of units: Long Ship, Dragon Ship, Chieftain, Vikings, Berserkers, and Scout. The mainland forces consist of three types of units: Peasant Militia, Men at Arms, and Knights. The number of mainland units encountered depends on the type of settlement discovered. Settlement types include Farm, Village, Church, Town, City, and Castle.

At the start of the game, the land masses on the mapsheet are blank. The terrain and settlements are filled in as the players explore the map.

name: Whale Hunters
description:
"Card game for 2-4 players. Early 19th Century Whale Hunting Theme."

"Scale: Each Player represents one Whaling Ship of European/American Identity. One Game represents one Whaling Season."

"Game End: The Game ends when players have gone through the deck twice."

"Victory: At the end of the game the player with the most Blubber Tokens wins."

An optional rule allows they players to represent particular Whaling Nations. There is also a solitaire dice based variant which replaces the cards with tables.
categories: Animals, Card Game, Industry / Manufacturing, Nautical, Print & Play

name: Jeson Mor
description:
Jeson Mor ("9 horses") is a two-player board game played on a 9x9 checkerboard that originates in Mongolia. This game was described in "The Encyclopedia of Chess Variants" (by David Pritchard).

Each horse moves like the Chess knight.
The goal of the game is to move one of your own horses to the middle cell of the board and then to move that horse outside the middle cell.

A player also wins if he captures all opponent's horses.

name: Dipole Chess
description:
This game is a cross between regular chess and Mark Steere's Dipole. The game is won by either capture your opponent's King instead of checkmating, or by having your opponent not be able to move any pieces. This is done by restricting non-capture movement to only moving forward (straight or diagonally), rather than laterally or backwards. Castling remains the same as in normal chess, and pieces may capture as the do normally, including laterally or backwards.

This small change in the results results in a game that last only a finite number of turns, and with one side guaranteed a win. Even though the game is more restrictive in some regards over normal chess, it is still a deep game. Due to the game being a cross between Dipole and normal chess, it bears the name Dipole Chess. Fans of chess and Dipole should consider checking this game out.

The latest version of the game rules for Dipole Chess can be found here:
http://www.chessvariants.org/index/msdisplay.php?itemid=MSdi...

A Zillions adaptation of the game can be found here:
http://www.zillionsofgames.com/cgi-bin/zilligames/submission...;id=1617

name: Overlords
description:
A fantasy game for two players. The object is to capture the opposing Overlord to become the one true Overlord. Each player starts with one each of the following pieces: Overlord, Hero, Wizard, and Dragon.

The game is played on an 8x8 grid or chess board. Four of each of the following features are randomly distributed on the board: Castles, Towers, Dragon Lairs, Bottomless Pits, and Mountains.

The Pits and Mountains represent barriers. The other locations are places where units may be recruited - Heroes from Castles, Wizards from Towers, and Dragons from Dragon Lairs.

name: Victorian Villains
description:
Heroes and villains of history and literature battle in this game of Victorian Era adventure.

Each player uses a separate deck, one for the heroes and one for the villains. Heroes portrayed in the game include Sherlock Holmes, Van Helsing, Tarzan, and Philieas Fog. Villains include Dr. Fu-Man-Chu, Jack the Ripper, and Thugee Assassins.

Masterminds attract Minions. Inventors and Scientists craft fantastic vehicles and weapons. Martian Tripods attempt world conquest. These events and more occur during the thirteen phases of each turn: New Day Phase, Genius Phase, Healing Phase, Minion Phase, Invention Phase, Recruit Phase, Plot Phase, Spy Phase, Assassin Phase, Plot Phase, Intercept Phase, Track Phase, and Attack Phase.

The goal is to eliminate all of your opponent's major characters. The first player to do so after the fifth turn wins the game.
categories: Card Game, Fighting, Novel-based, Science Fiction

name: Whakka Mole
description:
Whakka Mole is a game of bluffing and brinkmanship for two people looking to vent a little aggression. Each turn you get to select which moles pop out of your mole holes while selecting one of your opponents’ holes to whack. You get points for whacking your opponent’s moles, and by keeping your moles from being whacked.

Whakka Mole uses about 10 tokens per player, a custom sheet that you can download, and pencil and paper. A two-player game takes 5 to 10 minutes to play. Whakka Mole is appropriate for Ages 10 and up.

name: Empire
description:
Empire is light civilization-building game, played using 4 shared decks of cards. In that respect, it bears some similarity to games such as San Juan or Race for the Galaxy, but with added combat and resource-development elements reminiscent of Magic: the Gathering. The game, the first offering by fledgling publisher Gurushar Games, provides 2 to 4 players six different paths to victory: either by amassing 80 Gold (a measure of the civilization's wealth), 30 Order (a measure of infrastructure and governmental improvements), or 10 Support (a measure of the civilization's morale). Alternatively, a player may attempt to reduce their opponent's Gold, Order, or Support to 0, thus eliminating them from the game.
Similarly to Magic: the Gathering, Resource (i.e. land) cards, such as farms or villages, are played, and then taxed to produce Gold. This Gold is then spent to play more Resources. It is also possible to use this Gold to buy Units (which defend the land, or can attack an opponent's Order), or Systems (e.g. Democracy, Capitalism, Martial Law), which provide permanent upgrades to a player's capabilities. Alternatively, your Gold may be spent to trigger 1-time Event cards, or simply hoarded to reach the 80-Gold victory condition.

name: Assault at Cold Harbor
description:
Solitaire tactical American Civil War game re-creating the battle of Cold Harbor near Richmond, VA from May 31-June 12, 1864.

Reprinted in a separate (ziplock) printing from its original appearance in Panzerschreck #3 (1999) as "Cold Harbor II" with map, counters and rules that "are slightly modified from the original edition". Reprinted again in 2015 in Panzer Digest #12 as "Assault at Cold Harbor" with color map and counters and updated rules.

Description: The player (Union) makes a frontal assault against entrenched Confederate positions in the hope of achieving a breakthrough.

name: Wizards of Soccer
description:
Complete MagicSoccer Card Game
Created and illustrated by Alessandro Dolcetta

It is a complete deck of cards composed of
36 Offensive Cards
36 defensive Cards
8 Team cards
5 Ball Cards
2 Yellow Cards
4 Red Cards
1 Rule sheet

The game is a funny simulation of a Soccer match, played by Wizards, that with their Spells Cards try to advance the ball onto the opposite net to score a Goal.
First who score two Goals wins or you can play by time.

It is an easy game where offensive and defensive player, play simultaneously their Card. Depending on the position on the field (formed by 16 cards)you match different combos that may be a dribbling, a shoot, an interception, a corner or... a goal!

Cards are easy to read: they just report the name of the offensive or defensive spells (in Latin) and the number power of that spell.
The different colours of the cards background greatly help to recognize each of them when you have your hand of 11 cards.

Very good for children, for the coloured "comics" illustrations, and families that wish to relax with a simple, easy game.

On the Author website
www.alex-games.com
find plenty of info also in english, pictures and descriptions.

Wizards of Soccer will be present at
Angelo Porazzi Games Booth 9-30 Essen 2008
with English rulesheet
mechanics: Modular Board, Open Drafting, Simultaneous Action Selection

name: Kron, el bosque maldito
description:
"Super Juegos" was a pioneer Spanish magazine about both, board and computer games, which was published between 1984-1985. Every issue included a board game inside, with rules and cut-out counters. As far as I know only eight numbers were published, at least in its first epoch (another publication with the same name would appear years later, this time focusing on computer games only).

"Kron, el bosque maldito" ("Kron, the Cursed Forest") appeared in issue 4 and was kind of a fantasy wargame where up to 6 players gathered warriors and wizards groups that fought evil creatures while searching for treasures.

name: Battle of Adrianople (378 AD)
description:
“The Roman Empire was feeling increasing pressure from the German tribes on its border. The German tribes were themselves suffering at the hands of the Huns. The Romans agreed to allow the Visigoths to move through Roman territory to escape the marauding Huns. Relations soon soured, however, and the Visigoths began raiding the villages in their path."

"Valens, the Eastern Emperor, led his army to fight the Visigoths and sent a request for help to the Western Emperor. When Valens reached Adrianople he decided to attack alone rather than waiting for the Western Army. It was a fatal mistake.”

A miniatures wargame intended for classroom use with two teams of students (grades 6-8). The game is designed to be played on a 7.5x5 foot table using 1/72 scale plastic miniatures mounted two per base. Free print-and-play paper miniatures are also provided for use with the rules. Units portrayed in the game include Infantry, Cavalry, Skirmishers, and Roman Generals.

name: Battle of Hattin (1187 AD)
description:
A recreation of the Battle of Hattin.

“In 1170 AD a new, powerful leader rose to lead the Muslim counterattack. For a while Saladin, as he was known in the West, maintained an uneasy peace with the crusaders. However a series of provocations by the crusaders broke the truce and finally forced his hand."

"He gathered a large army and laid siege to Tiberias. The Crusaders went for the bait and marched to the rescue. Their line of march took them across a desert where the heavily armored knights suffered terribly in the summer heat. Saladin sent soldiers to harass them during the march, slowing their advance to a crawl."

"The army was dying of thirst when they approached Lake Tiberias only to find Saladin’s army blocking their path. In the battle that followed the crusader army was destroyed. Raymond of Tripoli was the only commander to escape, the other the crusader leaders were killed or captured. Saladin’s forces also capture a treasured holy relic – the ‘True Cross.’”

A miniatures wargame intended for classroom use with two teams of students (grades 6-8). The game is designed to be played using 1/72 scale plastic miniatures or free print-and-play paper miniatures provided with the rules.

name: Bombers Over Germany
description:
“The B-17 Flying Fortress was the principal heavy bomber of the US during WW II. The plane was used for daylight bombing missions against industrial targets in Europe and, to a lesser extent, the Pacific Theatre . . . Often the B-17s would be accompanied by escort fighters such as the P-47 and P-51.”

A simple historical miniatures air combat game designed for classroom use in grades 6-8. The game is played by two teams representing the American and German forces. The American players have eight B-17 bombers and eight escort fighters, each divided into two squadrons. The German players have sixteen fighters divided into four squadrons and a fifth squadron containing four jet fighters. The German players attempt to shoot down as many bombers as possible before the bombers can move off the end of the board or time runs out.

Designed to be played using 1/144 scale models and a 7.5x5 foot mat hex map using hexes that are about three inches across. Free print-and-play paper aircraft models are also provided for use with the rules.
categories: Aviation / Flight, Educational, Miniatures, Wargame, World War II

name: WW II Aerial Combat
description:
“At the start of World War II some pilots were still flying obsolete bi-planes. By the end of the war Germany had entered the jet age . . . The Battle of Britain was fought in the skies. The Allies had to gain air superiority before they could launch the D-Day invasion . . . In the Pacific the Japanese aircraft carriers dominated the seas. Only after four Japanese carriers (and many veteran pilots) were destroyed at the Battle of Midway did the United States turn the tables . . . In the end, the war was ended with atomic bombs delivered by bombers.”

A simple historical miniatures air combat game of World War Two fighter combat designed for classroom use. The game may be played by eight players using 1/144 or 1/72 scale models on a large hex grid (a 4x4 foot piece of blue chart paper marked with five inch hexes is recommended).

Each player uses an aircraft model (American, British, Russian, or Japanese), a deck of maneuver cards, a laminated record card (for tracking damage and victories with a dry erase marker), and 5 six-sided dice. Each record card includes the name and picture of a World War Two ace, his victory total, and brief biographical information.

An optional rule provides specific characteristics for a number of different historical fighter aircraft. The aircraft are rated in a number of categories: the ability to sustain damage, offensive capability, and maneuverability. Statistics are given for fourteen different aircraft, including the Me-109, FW-190, Me-262, Spitfire, Hurricane, Mustang, Lightning, and Zero.
categories: Aviation / Flight, Educational, Miniatures, Wargame, World War II

name: WW II Aerial Combat Fast and Easy Rules
description:
A miniatures air combat game for use at conventions or with history classes.

The game may be played with 1/144 scale models or similar miniatures. Free print-and-play paper aircraft models are also provided for use with the rules. The playing board is a large hex mat with hexes about four inches in size. A five foot square map is suggested for fighter dogfights and a larger mat is needed for scenarios involving bombing runs.

Statistics are included for twenty-five fighters and fourteen bombers from World War Two. Each fighter is rated for crew, guns, speed, turn, immelman, and hit points. Each bomber is rated for crew, speed, turn, hit points, bombs, guns in each of five positions (nose, top, belly, side, and tail), and bomber type (fighter bomber, light, medium, or heavy). In addition, a conversion table is included for determining game ratings for additional historical aircraft based on performance data.

Movement sequence is determined randomly each turn by drawing cards until each aircraft or bomber squadron has had a chance to move and fire. Combat is resolved by a die roll. Victory conditions vary depending on the scenario.
categories: Aviation / Flight, Educational, Miniatures, Wargame, World War II

name: Mig Madness: Jet vs. Jet Combat
description:
“The Korean War included several major surprises: the North's invasion of the South, the Inchon landings, and the intervention of China. Another surprise came when the Russian built Mig-15 jet started flying in the skies over North Korea. It dominated the skies and took a heavy toll on UN bombers, especially the B-29s."

"The US sent in the F-86 Sabre to fight for air supremacy. Jet vs. jet dogfights took place in ‘Mig Alley,’ an area just south of the Yalu River which marked the border with China. UN pilots were not allowed to cross the Yalu, a rule they sometimes ignored. Badly outnumbered and hampered by early technical problems, the Sabre pilots struggled at the start. In time they would turn the tide, and by the end of the war they would have the upper hand.”

A simple historical miniatures air combat game designed for classroom use in grades 6-8. The game may be played by eight players using 1/144 scale models on a Battle Masters mat (4x4 feet with five inch hexes).

Each player uses an aircraft model (F-86 or MiG-15), a deck of maneuver cards, a laminated record card (for tracking damage and victories with a dry erase marker), and 5 six-sided dice. Each record card includes the name of a Korean War ace, his victory total, and brief biographical information.
categories: Aviation / Flight, Educational, Korean War, Miniatures, Wargame

name: Fightin' for the Pharaoh
description:
“The chariot was an effective weapon during the Bronze Age. In Egypt they favored a light, highly maneuverable chariot from which the rider could fire arrows at the enemy. The Hittites used a heavier chariot designed to drive into the enemy, delivering a heavy blow at close quarters."

"The two empires came into conflict over the rich lands of Syria, which lay between their respective spheres of influence. Pharaoh Rameses II was the first to arrive at the strategic city of Kadesh. He settled into a fortified camp to await the arrival of the rest of his army. Only he didn't arrive first. King Muwatallish was camped near by, with his entire army. The Hittite king sent a stong force of chariots to attack.”

A miniatures wargame of the Battle of Kadesh (1300 BC) intended for classroom use with two teams of students (grades 6-8).

The game is designed to be played on a 7.5x5 foot table using 1/72 scale plastic miniatures, with foot units mounted two per base and chariots mounted singly. Free print-and-play paper miniatures are also provided for use with the rules. There is also a print-and-play shield wall which may be used to represent the boundaries of the Egyptian camp.

Units portrayed in the game include Egyptian Infantry, Archers, and the Sherden Guards of Pharaoh Ramses II, as well as the Hittite and Egyptian Chariots.

name: Battle of the Barons
description:
A classroom game for six groups of history students, grades 6 to 8.

“This simulation is about feudal Europe from 700 AD - 1200 AD, the late Middle Ages. The simulation is not set in any specific part of Europe, and the term ‘baron’ is used to refer to nobles. It is intended to familiarize the students with some of the basic characteristics of life in the Middle Ages: the feudal system, the church, the crusades, castles, political marriages, etc. With modifications it could be used for similar civilizations in other places and times, such as feudal Japan. This simulation is intended to be played one or two turns per week, with each turn taking 10 - 15 minutes, while the students are studying a unit on this topic.”

The game is played on a hex-shaped hex map, five hexes on a side. The game also requires a standard deck of playing cards (used to resolve battles and determine the death of barons) and a set of event cards that must be created.

“The students should be divided into 6 groups. You can play with more groups, but in that case you should use a larger map. Each group represents a noble family. You can assign the students roles if you wish: Baron, Baroness, Seneschal, and Bailiff. Each team will be given control of a fiefdom. This consists of their home hex and the six surrounding hexes.”

“Objective: The goal of each team is to become the most powerful baron. This is measured by their fame. Fame represents the reputation and status of the baron. Another important measure of a baron's power is how many hexes he controls. This will determine how large an army he can call up for battles, and how much gold he will collect in taxes from his territory.”

name: The Battle of Marathon
description:
“The mighty Persian Empire was more than a little annoyed when the Greeks encouraged the Ionians to revolt. After crushing the revolt King Darius decided to punish the upstarts. In 490 BC he led an army of over 40,000 soldiers into Greece. There they faced a force of 10,000 Athenians on the plains of Marathon. The Athenians surprised the Persians by charging them. The strategy worked, and they routed the much larger force, driving them into the sea.”

A miniatures wargame intended for classroom use with two teams of students (grades 6-8). The game is designed to be played using 1/72 scale plastic miniatures mounted two per base. Free print-and-play paper miniatures are also provided for use with the rules. Units portrayed in the game include Infantry, Javelin Skirmishers, Archer Skirmishers, Commanders, Greek Sling Skirmishers, and Persian Immortals.

name: The Battle of Chaeronea, 338 BC
description:
“Fought near Chaeronea, in Boeotia, this was the greatest victory of Philip II of Macedon. There, Philip (with 32,000 men) defeated the smaller combined forces of Athens and Thebes, securing Macedonian hegemony in Greece. The battle itself pitted the classical phalanx of the Athenian and Theban confederates and the Macedonian phalanx of Philip.”

A miniatures wargame intended for classroom use. The Macedonian units portrated in the game include the Companion Cavalry, Pikemen, Skirmishers, and Commanders (Phillip and Alexander). The Greek units include Athenian and Theban Hoplites, Skirmishers, and the Theban Sacred Band.

The designer states: “This game was designed for an advanced 5th grade class studying classical Greece. I picked Charoenea because I didn't have any Persian figures, and because I thought it would be fun for them to get to see Alexander on the battlefield . . . The Greeks probably don't have much chance in this scenario, I'm afraid, and the players should be prepared for this. It is more a historical simulation than a ‘fair’ game. There were 8 students, but the game is designed for 9 players.”

name: Fast Play Rules for the Battle of Towton (1461)
description:
“The War of the Roses (1455 - 1487) was an English civil war fought between the House of York and the House of Lancaster."

"The Yorkists won a major victory at the Battle of Towton. Fought on Palm Sunday, 29th April 1461, this battle confirmed the newly crowned Edward IV, son of Richard Duke of York, as king. Many of the important Lancastrian nobles either died in the battle, or were executed afterwards. The battle was the bloodiest fought on British soil and was fought in a snowstorm.”

This miniatures wargame is designed to be played using 1/72 scale plastic miniatures mounted two per stand. Free print-and-play paper miniatures are also provided for use with the rules. Units portrayed in the game include Longbowmen, Billmen, and dismounted Men-at-Arms.

A 5x5 foot table is required for play, but an alternate setup is provided to permit a larger version of the battle to be played on an 8x8 table.

name: The Siege of Louisbourg 1745 & 1758
description:
“The Fortress of Louisbourg was one of the largest fortifications the French constructed in North America . . . Louisbourg was destined to fall to a New England army in 1745 and a professional British Army in 1758.”

“The 1745 siege was conducted by an army raised by the colonial governments of New England who raised, equipped, supplied and transported their army to Louisbourg in the summer of 1745. They only had some naval help from the British. This army of farmers, tradesmen and craftsmen were able to defeat and capture an important French settlement."

"The siege of 1758 was as a result of the British Government's strategy of weakening France by capturing her overseas Empire. A British army of 15,000 soldiers and sailors was dispatched from Britain to Halifax, Nova Scotia to train and then launch an attack on the Fortress. The French this time were ready for an invasion and had prepared beach defenses. However, the British were still able to land and after a seven week siege, the French surrendered. The French commander had achieved his objective of delaying the British advance on Quebec for another year.”

A miniatures wargame intended for classroom use with two teams of students (grades 6-8). The game is designed to be played on a 2x1 meter table using 1/72 scale miniature figures. Free print-and-play paper miniatures are also provided for use with the rules, as well as a print-and-play castle to be used for the fortress.

The game covers a small area of the siege, near a gate and bastion. A wet moat protects a portion of the fortress by the gate. The only units involved in the sieges are infantry and artillery.
categories: Age of Reason, Educational, Miniatures, Wargame

name: Battle of King's Mountain (1780 AD)
description:
“The Battle of King’s Mountain was not fought between British troops and American Regulars. It was Americans fighting against their neighbors, family and friends. Major Ferguson was the Loyalist commander and was a part of Lord Cornwallis’ army."

"On October 7th 1780, Ferguson set up a camp on King’s Mountain. The Continental Army under the command of Col. Shelby surrounded Ferguson on the mountain and proceeded to shoot down his men. Some of the Americans had rifles and were able to pick off the Loyalists at the top of the hill. The Loyalists attempted to drive off the Patriots with bayonet charges but each time they were cut down by musket and rifle fire.”

A miniatures wargame intended for classroom use with two teams of students (grades 6-8). The game is designed to be played on a 2x1 meter table using 1/72 scale plastic miniatures. Free print-and-play paper miniatures are also provided for use with the rules.

The center of the game table is dominated by the mountain. The Loyalist forces begin deployed around the camp on top of the mountain, while the Patriots deploy anywhere around the mountain. To win the game the Patriots must capture or remove all Loyalist troops from the mountain and kill Major Ferguson.
categories: Age of Reason, American Revolutionary War, Educational, Miniatures, Wargame

name: Battle of Granicus (334 BC)
description:
“Philip II of Macedonia built a powerful army and used it to bring all of Greece under his rule. After his assassination in 336 BC Philip’s 20-year-old son Alexander inherited the throne. Alexander promptly crossed the Hellespont into Turkey intent on conquering the mighty Persian Empire."

"The first major battle came at the Granicus River. Alexander led his elite Companion cavalry across the river to draw the attention of the Persians. It worked, almost too well. Alexander was nearly killed when the Persians counterattacked, but the tactic worked. Alexander’s Macedonian phalanxes were able to cross the river and defeat the Persian army.”

A miniatures wargame intended for classroom use with two teams of students (grades 6-8). The game is designed to be played on a 7.5x5 foot table using 1/72 scale plastic miniatures mounted two per base. Free print-and-play paper miniatures are also provided for use with the rules. The units portrayed in the game include Infantry, Cavalry, Skirmishers (Javelins and Archers), and Commanders.

name: Across the Alps: The Battle of Trebbia (218 BC)
description:
“The Second Punic War between Rome and Carthage began in 218 BC. In the winter of that year Hannibal crossed the Alps and invaded Italy with a large army."

"The first major engagement came near the Trebbia River where a Roman army confronted the invaders. The battle was a disaster for the Romans. Hannibal encircled them with the help of a surprise attack on the Roman rear led by his brother Mago. The Roman army broke and routed across the river with heavy casualties.”

A miniatures wargame intended for classroom use with two teams of students (grades 6-8). The game is designed to be played on a 7.5x5 foot table using 1/72 scale plastic miniatures mounted two per base, except for elephants and commanders which are mounted singly. Free print-and-play paper miniatures are also provided for use with the rules. Units portrayed in the game include Commanders, Cavalry, Infantry, Skirmishers, and Elephants.

name: Don't Mess with Hannibal
description:
“In the year 216 BC the Second Punic War had become a stalemate. The Romans could not defeat Hannibal's Carthaginian army in the field, and Hannibal could not capture Rome."

"Growing impatient, Rome raised a large army and set them under the command of Caius Varro to battle Hannibal. The result was one of the most devastating defeats ever inflicted on an army. Varro was determined that his army would not be outflanked and defeated by Hannibal, as happened at the battle of Trebbia. But Hannibal was one of the greatest generals in military history, and that's exactly what happened. The Romans were encircled and massacred.”
A miniatures wargame intended for classroom use with two teams of students (grades 6-8). The game is designed to be played on a 7.5x5 foot table using 1/72 scale plastic miniatures mounted two per base. Free print-and-play paper miniatures are also provided for use with the rules. Units portrayed in the game include Commanders, Infantry, Cavalry, and Skirmishers.

name: The Battle of Zama
description:
“In the second century BC the rich trading empire of Carthage vied with the rising Roman Republic for control of the Mediterranean. In the Second Punic War Carthage's legendary general, Hannibal, surprised the Romans by crossing the Alps and invading their homeland. His army was too tough for the Romans to defeat on the field of battle, but not tough enough to capture Rome. Finally the Romans sent a young and ambitious general named Scipio to invade Carthage. The ploy worked, and Hannibal was summoned home to defend the city.”

“The decisive battle was fought in Zama, in Northern Africa. The battle featured contrasting armies: the citizen soldiers of the Roman Legions against the mercenary army of Carthage. The two sides were closely matched. The Carthaginian army included close to one hundred poorly trained war elephants. The tuskers were mostly ineffective against the well-prepared Romans.”
A miniatures wargame intended for classroom use with two teams of students (grades 6-8). The game is designed to be played on a 7.5x5 foot table using 1/72 scale plastic miniatures mounted two per base. Free print-and-play paper miniatures are also provided for use with the rules. Units portrayed in the game include Commanders, Elephants, Infantry, Cavalry, Skirmishers, and Roman “Scorpion” Artillery.

name: The Die is Cast: The Battle of Pharsalus (48 BC)
description:
“Rome was the scene of civil unrest. The Senate needed a strong leader to restore order, but they feared creating a dictator. They decided to appoint three men to share command - Julius Caesar, Pompey, and Crassus."

"The plan began to unravel when Crassus was killed in Egypt. This set up a power struggle between Caesar, who was in Gaul, and Pompey who was in Rome. Caesar stopped at the Rubicon River with his army. He knew that if he crossed the river it would mean civil war, a gamble that might cost him his life."

"With the famous words ‘the die is cast’ he crossed the river, sparking a civil war with Pompey's supporters. The decisive battle of the war was fought in 48 BC at Pharsalus. Caesar was triumphant. Pompey fled to Egypt, where he was killed. Casesar became dictator, turning the Roman Republic into the Roman Empire in the process.”

A miniatures wargame intended for classroom use with two teams of students (grades 6-8). The game is designed to be played on a 7.5x5 foot table using 1/72 scale plastic miniatures mounted two per base. Free print-and-play paper miniatures are also provided for use with the rules. Units portrayed in the game include Commanders, Cavalry, Infantry, and Skirmishers.

name: Rupert's Very Bad Day: Battle of Marston Moor (1644 AD)
description:
“The first English Civil War (1642 - 1645) was a power struggle between King Charles I and his royalist supporters on the one hand, and Parliament and its supporters on the other. At the battle of Marston Moor (1644) a Parliamentarian army reinforced by a Scots army decisively defeated the Royalists. It was a humiliating defeat for the dashing Prince Rupert (his poodle was among the many Royalist casualties). The battle left the Parliamentarians in control of the north of England.”

A miniatures wargame intended for classroom use with two teams of students (grades 6-8). The game is designed to be played on a 7.5x5 foot table using 1/72 scale plastic miniatures mounted two per stand. Free print-and-play paper miniatures are also provided for use with the rules. Units portrayed in the game include commanders, musketeers, pikemen, and artillery.
categories: Educational, Miniatures, Pike and Shot, Wargame

name: Will You Go Upon Your Death?
description:
“The first English Civil War (1642 - 1645) was a power struggle between King Charles I and his Royalist supporters on the one hand, and Parliament and its supporters on the other. At the battle of Naseby (1645) the Parliamentarian New Model Army scored a major victory, thanks in large part to the exploits of Oliver Cromwell's cavalry. With his army on the brink of defeat King Charles was prepared to personally lead his reserves into battle. A subordinate asked the King ‘Will you go upon your death?’ The King decided to retreat instead of continue the fight. This defeat effectively ended the hopes of the Royalists.”

A miniatures wargame intended for classroom use with two teams of students (grades 6-8). The game is designed to be played on a 7.5x5 foot table using 1/72 scale plastic miniatures mounted two per stand. Free print-and-play paper miniatures are also provided for use with the rules.

Units portrayed in the game include commanders, musketeers, and pikemen. Players are also given the option to include cannons in the game, but these units are not included in the standard setup given that they failed to have a significant impact in the actual battle.
categories: Educational, Miniatures, Pike and Shot, Wargame

name: Great Northern War: Kliszow (1702)
description:
“Charles XII became the King of Sweden in 1697 at the age of fifteen. He inherited a sizable empire and one of the best armies in the world. Sweden's rivals thought they could take advantage of the young King. The Great Northern War (1700 - 1721) was a military struggle between Sweden on one side, and Russia, Denmark, and Saxony-Poland on the other."

"At the Battle of Kliszow Charles XII invaded Poland to try and knock Saxony-Poland out of the war. Although outnumbered the Swedes won an impressive victory, thanks in large part to their outstanding cavalry. The Swedes were unable to follow up their victory, however, and the Saxons would remain a problem for Charles XII for years to come.”

A miniatures wargame intended for classroom use with two teams of students (grades 6-8). The game is designed to be played on a 7.5x5 foot table using 1/72 scale plastic miniatures. Free print-and-play paper miniatures are also provided for use with the rules.

The order of battle for each army (Swedish and Saxon) is broken down according to the position of the units on the battlefield: the left wing, right wing, or center. Each wing has a separate commander and each army has an overall commander. According to the rules, the Polish Army is not included in the setup because those forces were routed soon after the fighting began.
categories: Age of Reason, Educational, Miniatures, Wargame

name: Farewell to Flanders
description:
“The War of the Spanish Succession (1701-1714) began when the King of Spain died without an heir. King Louis XIV of France and Emperor Leopold I of Austrian both claimed the throne, and Spain's territory. England and the Netherlands sided with Austria, while Bavaria joined the French."

"At the start of the war the French army had a reputation as the best in Europe. At the battle of Ramillies (1706) the Duke of Marlborough soundly defeated the French. The French defeat had the effect of driving the French out of the Spanish Netherlands (which included Flanders).”

A miniatures wargame intended for classroom use with two teams of students (grades 6-8). The game is designed to be played on a 7.5x5 foot table using 1/72 scale plastic miniatures. Free print-and-play paper miniatures are also provided for use with the rules.

The order of battle for each army (Confederate and French) is broken down according to the position of the units on the battlefield: the left wing, right wing, or center. Each wing has one or more commanders, and each army has an overall commander. A number of terrain features must be marked on the game table – namely four fortified towns and a stream which extends into the battlefield between the two armies.
categories: Age of Reason, Educational, Miniatures, Wargame

name: I Will Treat With the Tsar in Moscow
description:
“Charles XII became the King of Sweden in 1697 at the age of fifteen. He inherited a sizable empire and one of the best armies in the world. Sweden's rivals thought they could take advantage of the young King. The Great Northern War (1700 - 1721) was a military struggle between Sweden on one side, and Russia, Denmark, and Saxony-Poland on the other."

"In 1708 Charles XII launched an invasion of Russia, determined to capture Moscow and force the Tsar to accept a peace treaty that favored Sweden. The Russians dug in behind the River Vabitch to try and block the invasion. Charles surprised the Russians by crossing the river and marshland at night and appearing suddenly on the right flank of the trench line. The disorganized Russians were forced out of their prepared positions and fought in the open and in the woods. The Swedes suffered heavy casualties but were able to succeed in opening the door to an invasion of Russia.”

A miniatures wargame intended for classroom use with two teams of students (grades 6-8). The game is designed to be played on a 7.5x5 foot table using 1/72 scale plastic miniatures. Free print-and-play paper miniatures are also provided for use with the rules.

The order of battle for each army (Swedish and Russian) is broken down into two groups according to the position of the units on the battlefield: the left wing or right wing. Each side also has a reinforcement group which enters after the start of the battle. Each wing has one or more commanders, and each army has an overall commander. The only terrain features addressed in the rules are several wooded areas that may be designated by simply drawing their borders on the playing surface.
categories: Age of Reason, Educational, Miniatures, Wargame

name: Peter Aces His Final Exam
description:
“The Great Northern War (1700 - 1721) was a military struggle between Sweden on one side, and Russia, Denmark, and Saxony-Poland on the other. The Swedish army under Charles XII was among the best in the Europe, and would win many victories. However the end result of the war was a defeat for Sweden that ended her run as a world power and cost her much of her empire. In 1708 Charles XII launched an invasion of Russia."

"In June of 1709 the decisive battle of the campaign was fought at Poltava. The Swedes attempted a surprise attack on the Russian's fortified camp.
